. Hi @iapain 
In the latest devv branch, I've change the default behaviour when --tounicode=0
Basically when **--tounicode=1**, the ToUnicode Map will be forced applied, when **--tounicode=-1**, the map will be completely ignored.

When **--tounicode=0**, the map is attempted to be applied. If anything wrong is found, it'll be dropped.

I changed the behaviour because I have received many PDF files where there are Type 1 fonts embedded without proper font names in the font, whereas proper ToUnicode CMaps are provided. These are actually more consistent with the PDF Standard.

What do you say about it?

. Thanks for reporting, but please open a new issue instead of simply leaving message here.

pdf2htmlEX is a converter, it always follows the original content in PDF. So if you see spaces among letter, that would means there ARE spaces in the PDF. And it's not possible for pdf2htmlEX to recognize the words.

About zooming, indeed there are problems for different browsers, the problem should not be with the spaces, but font sizes. The browser may round the font size, such that letter will be larger or smaller than they should be. To check if it's the problem you saw, just zoom in, when the letters are large enough, there should never be any problem with font sizes (and thus spaces). 

Currently I don't have any solutions to this, but you may want to check the manpage about the --font-size-multiplier parameter.
. Can you point out the location of the word 'arbeitsmarkt' in the PDF? or
show me a pdf with only that word. I want to compare the visuals.

I didn't mean ' ' either, but consider this:

In PDF, almost everything is absolutely positioned. For the word apple,
suppose all letter are of width 10px, in PDF, the following two operations
should be the same

(1) write 'apple' at (0,0) with font size 10px
(2) write 'app' at (0,0) and 'le' at (30,0), both with font size 10px

and there is no ' '

(2) actually often appears in PDF, I don't know why but it's the truth.

pdf2htmlEX cannot and will not recognize the word 'apple' in (2), and will
generate the HTML code you saw.

The problems when you zoom out, say 33%, idealy (2) should become
(2) write 'app' at (0,0) and 'le' at (10,0), with font size 3.33px.
But the browser may not be happy with '3.33px', it may use '3px' or '3.5px'
or something else, such that the letters may overlapped or be separated.

Also notice that there is no ' ' inside the <span> tag except for the last
one, which is correct.

. Why do you remove those js code?
They are not equivalent.
The js code loads the pages one by one asynchronously,
which prevents page rendering blocks UI events.
. With that line of CSS, the browser will still try to redraw everything
before it can response user's actions.

So when the browser loads all the pages gradually, it'll test if the new
node should be drawn.
With your CSS, still all nodes are drawn as soon as they are loaded,
meanwhile you can get no response of actions like scrolling, so the users
may feel stuck.

But with my CSS, all pages are hidden at first, so the browser knows that
there's nothing to draw at the beginning.
The JS tell the browser to set 'display:block' for each page, and the key
point is that it's done with setTimeOut, which is just a new event. And the
event is in the same queue as UI events (scrolling etc.) So user actions
can be responed before next pages are revealed.

. I see that the font for main text is not embedded, then in HTML the font is declared only with names and let browser to find a matching font.

Sometimes the matching font is the same as described in PDF, sometimes it is not; if it's not, PDF viewer may modify accordingly when rendering the file, but for HTML, the font has to be embedded in order to be modified.

maybe try --embed-base-font 1 ?

. So fontforge may built with or without spiro.
And pdf2htmlEX should be built in the same envrionment.

There's a macro _NO_LIBSPIRO defined (or not, if your fontforge was built
with spiro), and it affects header files like spinefont.h

According to your cmake log, config.h should be found, which should be in
the same folder as fontforge.h

One possible situation is that fontforge was built with spiro, but you
didn't install the headers of libspiro.
But everything should be fine if you compiled fontforge yourself.

. Hi, thank you for your attention and your thoughts.
First of all, I wrote this stuff for fun, but not to provide a great tool.

I'll definitely take consideration of the features you mentioned, but I'll just pick those attractive to me. Especially I don't want to do anything about UI, which is annoying to me. However, patches are always welcome.

I've actually using a little bit jquery there. You see everything is open now comparing to PDF, you can actually do anything you had imagined with JS, as you have full control of the document now.

About LaTeX,  yes, it's true that it'll be better if convert directly from LaTeX. But pdf2htmlEX is not for PDF generated by LaTeX only, and there needs lots of work dealing with the interfaces of LaTeX, that's not some trivial work.

For now, I guess LaTeX->PDF->HTML would be acceptable for most people.
. Hi, If you are focused on user experience only, I suggest you convert a simple PDF and read the generated HTML, it should be simple enough to understand, basically, absolute positioning + a few optimization.

If you want to change pdf2htmlEX itself, first I suggest you learn the PDF format a little bit, such that pdf2htmlEX itself will be quite straightforward.

Blog plot...hmm...., one problem is that the design is still being changed, I knew nothing about PDF format before I wrote pdf2htmlEX, and I'm still learning. It'd better if you ask a specific question, such that it'll be easier for me to answer.

. @deathlord87 What do you mean by UI? 

pdf2htmlEX should extract and provide enough information from the PDF file, such that UI interface can be implemented on top of it, for example, zoom/link/outline/thumbnails etc. pdf2htmlEX should provide no UI, because I assume that publisher is likely to design their own UI theme in order to to match their websites.

However there should be a demo UI, such that others may understand the structure of generated HTML better, you can actually find javascript script code in the repo. Currently what it does are:
- hide necessary pages ( set display:none )
- handle internal link jumps
- handle zoom in/out (disabled currently)

what's- missing for a demo UI include
- UI elements
  - buttons
  - navbar
- corresponding functions for UI elements above for the Viewer object
- effects

In principle, the Viewer object should be out-of-the-box providing necessary function, and UI designers may directly use them.

I suggest jQuery, because it's being used in the repo. Also there's a mobile version.

However as pdf2htmlEX is for general platforms, so I don't suggest use a mobile version directly.
. @deathlord87 I'm not familiar with Sencha Mobile, but I've used ExtJS, which is not lightweight enough to me.

> Lets look at this statistically
> 
> Total percent of users using a browser with
> some support for @font-face: 93.09%
> support for WOFF 76.61% (17% of users with some support excluded)
> support for TTF 66.47% full, 16.03% partial -> 82.5% total (11% of users
> with some support excluded totally, 27% with support))
> 
> Summary stats
> Best for IE -> EOT
> Best for firefox -> TTF/OTF
> Best for Chrome -> SVG/TTF/OTF
> Best for Safari -> TTF/OTF
> Best for Opera -> SVG
> Best for iOS Safari -> SVG
> Best for android -> TTF
> Best for blackberry -> TTF/OTF / SVG
> Best for opera mobile -> TTF/OTF/SVG
> Best for chrome for android -> TTF/OTF/SVG
> Best for firefox -> TTF/OTF/WOFF
> 
> Comments
> To support anything before IE 9 you need to use EOT. IE only has partial
> support of TTF with @font-face.
> To support old versions of iOS safari and opera you need SVG
> TTF/OTF seems to trump WOFF in terms of compatability in all respects
> however the smaller file size of WOFF is obviously prefered.
> 
> Stats from:
> http://caniuse.com/fontface
> http://caniuse.com/woff
> http://caniuse.com/ttf
> http://caniuse.com/svg-fonts
> http://caniuse.com/eot
> 
> To remedy this we can write fonts in all formats and then either:
> 
> A.) Use multiple font-face formats in the declaration. Font squirrel
> http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fontface/generator recommends the following
> as its "optimal" layout, "Recommended settings for performance and speed.".
> Its recommended by Paul Irish who knows his stuff and has done a long blog
> post on the ins and outs of @font-face declarations
> http://paulirish.com/2009/bulletproof-font-face-implementation-syntax/
> 
> @font-face {
> font-family: 'pragmataproregular';
> src: url('pragmatapro-webfont.eot');
> src: url('pragmatapro-webfont.eot?#iefix') format('embedded-opentype'),
> url('pragmatapro-webfont.woff') format('woff'),
> url('pragmatapro-webfont.ttf') format('truetype'),
> url('pragmatapro-webfont.svg#pragmataproregular') format('svg');
> font-weight: normal;
> font-style: normal;
> 
> }
> 
> Quick Explaination
> The first declaration is for IE9 / IE10 as EOT is the prefered font (IEs
> format so supposdely it does a good job at it).
> The second for IE8 and below. It will take the last src: statement as the
> one to use. IE8 and below have a bug in their parsers which results in 404s
> when more than one font is included in a src declaration. The ?#iefix
> tricks it into thinking everything after the ? is a query string and so it
> skips the other font formats.
> 
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8050640/how-does-iefix-solve-web-fonts-loading-in-ie6-ie8
> The woff, ttf and svg fonts are read by the rest of the browsers if they
> can read them (see above for importance of all types if maximising
> compatability).
> All browsers should only load one font so bandwidth really isn't an issue.
> 
> B.)
> If they do, we could take the aproach that scribd takes and detect
> browsers before injecting a css file containing the fonts in the most
> relevant format. This would require writing a separate css file for each
> font type which contains all required fonts.
> 
> Neither are too hard to implement and will result in increased support. I
> propose that we make A. the default as this version doesn't require JS.
>

. Hello, I've been busy with my own research for the past weeks, and just came back now.

Like @iapain said, I think pdftohtml or pdftotext might be the best choice for you, for now. 

I'm not sure what you want CSS removed, because even those are gone, still you cannot edit the HTML file generated (easily).

Things prevent easy editing include:
- The space padding between words, because in many PDF there are spaces of variant lengths.
- The lines are not reflowable, so if you change the length of a line, it will look ugly
- Fonts, often only necessary glyphs are embedded in PDF files, so if you introduce new characters, they won't show up correctly
  
  And the solutions to each of them:
- To remove the padding spaces with space characters, at the cost of alignment
- Reflowable text, I've tried once, but it's not only an issue of position, but also things like spelling, e.g. sometimes the dash at the end of a line should be removed in order to connect with the next line
- If the PDF file provides with a valid semantic encoding, you can easily substitute the font as you wish; otherwise I think you have to fix it manually.

The essential issue is that PDF has been designed for publishing, not editing.
. I'm going to try to implement the first two soon, and the third one is 'automatically' if there's a valid encoding.
. @404pnf Thanks for your explanation.

Converting pdf to html with corresponding tags would be quite difficult and annoying for me to do, as a hobby. That'd be recognition rather than conversion.

For example

table: to recognize aligned columns, as well as borders
li: not sure about this, maybe to recognize bullet?
h1/h2... : several rules based on the position and font sizes

To me, maybe h1/h2 would be the most difficult thing to do, because I cannot make a formula that works for all the PDF, the rules should be adaptive and adjustable, which might lead to lots of more options. I guess Acrobat does it well because it has lots of samples, and years of adjustment.

I remembered that pdftohtml can also export to xml, but didn't try it.

For now my concern is to output an html with reflowable and editable, making a small step towards structure-oriented html than visual-oriented.
. Indeed, Acrobat should have been guessing, but with more confidence with their well tuned heuristics

I'll implement unwarping lines, there have been a few people asking about editing the HTML, and publishers like @iapain also needs it. But it will be at the cost of losing some visual accuracy.

About file size, PDF supports in-file compression, while HTML does not, so it's not fair. But you can enable deflate on your http server. If you gzip the HTML file, most of time the file size is comparable with the original PDF.

Comparing with PDF.js. pdf2htmlEX started as a toy, as an alternate to PDF.js when a friend of mine needed to display PDF online. The problem with PDF.js (for now) is the slowness, and text handling. The advantage of pdf2htmlEX is all conversion/optimization is done background on the servers, which is done only once, such that they are not imposed on the users -- but seems that PDF.js will do a server-side version.

In short, pdf2htmlEX is for publishers, and PDF.js is for viewers.

The purpose of pdf2htmlEX is to provide a choice, for those who intended to publish in HTML, but was forced to PDF because the lack of tools. Also HTML, together with CSS and Javascript, allows better integration with your web site (themes, links etc), and more creative works --  how about google analytics embedded in your CV online? 

If you would like to help pdf2htmlEX, thank you and here are a few possibilities that you don't have to code.
- Just use it and report bugs.
- Credit it on your sites such that others would be aware of pdf2htmlEX
- Make a small donation if there is a commercial organization behind -- I'd suggest you make a feature request meanwhile

. As a start we may make some assumptions and start from the easiest case:

No header, footer, figure, table. And single column of text.

The task is to combine text lines in the same paragraph. We can further extend this to two-column layouts, as text rendering order is usually the same as reading order.

Spacing might be a problem, I think it's hard to preserve the exact spacing (width of letter-space, word-space, space-char), need to relax and estimate them.

The process should be easy if facilitated with manual marking/adjustments.

Ref: http://scribdtech.wordpress.com/2012/02/29/why-zooming-on-mobile-is-broken-and-how-to-fix-it/

Another direction is to tag the PDF in some way, and to utilize tag information in PDF file.

. You got the point.

Yes, for Linux and Mac, they use freetype or something similar, such that
fonts on screen look like the same as printed on papers - thanks to Apple
But Windows, with ClearType, focuses on "readable".

I think the fonts in PDF standards are similar with Linux/Mac, because I
can't quite tell the difference (visually) between a PDF file and a
converted HTML.
It should be so since PDF is a format for printing.

AFAIK Adobe Reader on Windows should render all fonts by itself, but web
browsers will call Windows API for this, by default the effect could be
very bad since most embedded fonts (in PDF) are lack of proper hinting --
the PDF viewer is supposed to handle this.

ttfautohint may add some hinting with freetype, which is currently the best
solution I have found.
I guess the --external-hint-tool is flexible enough for you, you just feed
a executable or script to it, and don't even need --single-html.

If you find a better solution, please tell me.

. No, the fonts are not identified by names, but internal IDs. It's possible
to embed the same font twice, with different IDs.

If you inspect the resources in the PDF files, you should see lots of fonts
with a same name.

About --remove-unused-glyph, an embedded font may contain some glyphs that
are never used in the PDF file, and these glyphs may be removed in order to
reduce the size of the font file.

. I found the reason.

That part of non-Type3 font is one of the default 14 fonts in PDF, which are not embedded and should be provided by the pdf viewer.

By default I'll translate them to proper font names, and the final result will depend on the environment of the viewer's browser, which is "undefined" theoretically, but should be fine most of the time.

You can force embedding fonts chosen by poppler, by specifying --embed-base-font 1, which would increase the size of HTML file. 

Please give a try and see if it helps.

- About the prefix --dont, or verbs with opposite meanings:

For example, when I first implemented auto-hint, it's not mature enough and is turned off by default; but later it can be enabled by default, I have to change it to --dont-auto-hint, and all scripts for older versions of pdf2htmlEX will be invalid.

. This issue has nothing to do with space-threshold. It's about font manipulation. If you copy the text out, you should not be able to see extra spaces inserted.

And to me, absolute positioning is much more than "occasional". I did not hear any complaints about `space-threshold`, so I believe the default value works for most PDF files.
. This PDF is kind of special, the reason you need to turn off
`squeeze-wide-glyph` is that the letter "M" is much narrower than it looks
like. If you select the word in the HTML, you may notice the thin highlight
box under "M".

The thin value is the actual width in the font, so if you actually write
"Man" with this font, you will see overlapping between M and a. There is no
overlapping in this PDF because there is position shift between M and a, or
a is absolute positioned. So logically, there is a quite wide gap there,
and inserting a space there is "logically" correct.

On the other hand, I cannot simply measure the gap between the actually
bounding boxes between glyphs, for example the letter 'Q' in the demo page
of pdf2htmlEX named "Typography".

I've just tested this PDF in Adobe Reader X, and I got "M nagement" copying
that word out.
. More info, the width of a glyph is how much you should shift the current
position horizontally before you can put the next glyph. And bounding box
is the actual size of the painted area of that glyph.

. The width of  'M' in the font is half as it looks like. Suppose 'M' looks
like 2mm width, and 'a' is 1mm width.
So for the word "Management", from the font renderer's point of view,
they're 1cm 'M' + 1cm gap + 1cm 'a'. And it should be OK if we insert a
space there.

A larger space-threshold should eat up this space, by design, but also eats
up all other spaces equal or less than this width, so other parts of the
document might be affected.

The main problem is the bad info in the embedded font in this PDF.

. In PDF, glyphs are positioned by the origin, so the ascent/descent info in embedded fonts are not useful.

But in HTML, all positioning rely on ascent/descent, so here I retrieve the actual value (instead of the values from the meta data of the embedded fonts in PDF) with Fontforge.

There are 3 sets of ascent/descent (win, os2, typo). When they are not consistent, different browsers may have different behaviors. So in `ffw_metric` I try to unify them.

. In the text coordinate system,  current position (tx,ty) marks the origin of the next character.
Depending on wmode or not, one of `char_dx` and `char_dy` should be 0. (Maybe there are other cases? I'm not 100% sure)
For horizontal text, char_dy is 0, and char_dx is the width of the next char.

Let `A=ascent * font_size` and `B=descent * font_size` (B is usually negative)
The BBox of the next char should be `(tx, ty+B) - (tx+dx, ty+A)`, so we need to test if this box is completely outside the clipping path.

. Sometimes yes. If you have installed poppler, there is a command `pdffonts` available. The first column shows the names.

The names are not reliable. The accuracy of the HTML depends on the metrics of the glyphs and the encoding of the font. There may be two sets of metrics stored in a PDF, one is defined in the embedded font, and the other stored in the font descriptor in PDF. When they are not consistent, the second one should be used, which means the font have to be transformed -- which can not be done by the browser.

Encoding, if you expect a good font at the client side, the text must be encoded in Unicode correctly, which is not reliable either -- there are too many PDF files whose text cannot be copied out correctly.

Since PDF is not designed for Web, actually I don't see these fonts often used in PDF (except for Times), at least in my test cases. You may verify this use `pdffonts`.

. @vineet89 Found the cause. The PDF maps the normal '-' into a soft hyphen, and the browsers will hide the symbol since the line does not break there. So essentially it's because the PDF provides a bad encoding.

Please update to the latest git version, and use `--to-unicode=-1`, which should fixes the problem.

However I'll need to test with more files, this behaviour may be changed later.
. @vineet89  Did you update your git repo? I can see a correct output here.

Let me briefly explain this:

In PDF there are two set of encodings, one for displaying (such that a PDF viewer can choose the correct glyphs to show), and the other is for text extraction (such that you can get correct text if you copy & paste). But there can be only one set in HTML, and sometimes it is not possible to achieve both visual accuracy and text accuracy (at least for now). 

In the case of this PDF file, the situation is slightly different, but if you select "xx-Nov-2012" and copy them out from a PDF viewer, I guess you don't see the hyphens, and the reason is that those are soft-hyphens, which should not be. This is provided by the '2nd set of encoding', and fortunately the 1st encoding is correct, and `--to-unicode=-1` forces pdf2htmlEX to use that set if possible. (When the 1st set is not even correct, there is no parameter right now, but maybe I can work out one)

For strictly standard compliant well-formed PDFs, you never need to worry about these issues, but in the wild world of PDF, I'm afraid that it might not be possible to find a set of parameters that works for all.

On the other hand, there are some possible hackings 
- Just convert all soft-hyphens into normal hyphens, since this symbol has special meaning in Unicode
- Mark `soft-hyphens` as invalid, just as NBSP

But none of them are perfect solutions, the first one may break the layout when both normal hyphens and soft hyphens appears in the font; and the second still does not give you correct text.

I wonder if I may hear some suggestions from you?
. @vineet89 Currently I decide to mark 'soft hyphen' as invalid, such that by default the HTML is visually correct.
This behaviour might be changed in the future, I hope I can find a better design later.
. @vineet89  The two sets of encodings are stored in the PDF, which can be any mappings. Currently if you add `--debug 1` and `--clean-tmp 0`, you will be able to find both sets of encodings in `/tmp/pdf2htmlEX-xxx`.

I've just tried again, and pdf2htmlEX gives correct output without any parameters. Please let me know if it doesn't work for you.

. I see that a "Hello" word in RTL language (such that you actually want to see "olleH") in placed left to right, char-by-char in PDF, such that it would be "olleH" in a normal (LTR) environment. After all PDF is designed for printing, so this is reasonable. 

However the browser would recognize the Hebrew characters and try to use the "correct" direction, such that it would be reversed again, into "Hello", which is wrong.

The best solution is to recognize the characters and reverse it, such that we can copy the correct text out. But I don't see a simple solution, given the complicated character positioning rules and the possibility of mixed usage of LTR and RTL languages.

. Hi @rcampbell , I just checked this issue again. The causes are:
- Browsers will round the font sizes specified in the page. [ref](http://meyerweb.com/eric/thoughts/2010/02/10/rounding-off/)
  - That's why `--font-size-multiplier` works
- In your PDF, a sentence is cut into two parts, the second part has a clipping path and therefore the two parts cannot be merged. Now due to the problem above, the first part is longer than we expected, so the end of the first part will overlap with the beginning of the second half.

This is indeed an issue of pdf2htmlEX, but probably not a 'bug'. So far I have no good solutions in my mind.

The vertical shift issue might be compensated by a smaller value of `--veps`.

Finally, I wonder why `--space-as-offset` would help, can you please give an example?

. Hi, the warning message is about malformed encoding inside PDF.
There are two sets of encodings in PDF, one for rendering and the other for Unicode, and pdf2thmlEX tries to merge them for HTML, but it is not always possible to do so. 

When `-tounicode` is not specified, pdf2htmlEX would try to ensure the visual correctness by reencoding some glyphs (but they will become garbage text when copied out). However if `--tounicode 1` is specified, the mapping defined in PDF will always be used even if some glyphs will become missing.

Theoretically this issue can be solved by creating extra fonts for the conflicted encoding, which is not worth the time at this moment. But I'll create an issue for that later anyway.

. As I remember, in PDF fonts do not have an attribute as 'normal' or 'bold', variants are just considered as different fonts. But the flag may still exists in the font file, which will be then interpreted by browsers.

Besides that flag, it's also possible to declare the weight in `@font-face`, I'm not sure how browsers decide the weight when one or both exist. E.g. in your case, 'bold' is declare in the font file but not in `@font-face`

Actually pdf2htmlEX guesses the style (see https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/blob/master/src/HTMLRenderer/font.cc#L1071) and tries to declare them in CSS. But basically it's based on font names.

. `--heps` is already a fault tolerance for spaces. There reason that you see so many tags is because they are spaces of different widths, say 1cm, 2cm or 3cm etc. If a standard space is 2cm, and `--heps` is small, then only 2cm spaces will be replaced with a space character; when `--heps` is at least `1cm`, all spaces between 1cm and 3cm will be replaced with a space character.

I don't have a better solution yet, can you propose one?
. You mean to use multiple characters for a single space?

. In my opinion this is a good feature, but the way you implemented might be too dirty.
I don't like the idea of doing the fallback in `CairoBackgroundRenderer`, a cleaner way is to do that outside them: 

```
auto img = cairo_renderer.render();
if(too_large(img))
    img = splash_render.render();
```

Another thing is that counting the number of `<`'s might be too hacky, are there any other ways to do thing, for example you can stop processing once you see too many tags generated.
. Better not touch `CairoOutputDev` files, these files are directly copied from poppler, which will be synced time to time. It's done like this because they are not exposed in poppler's API.

I do believe that counting '<' should work, it's just not that elegant.

Another way is just exit with an error message when there are too many nodes, and let the user to re run the program.
. Instead of using bitmap or something, the coordinator does not need to know
the details, it could be

```
cairo_dev.render();
if(!cairo_dev.ok())
   splash_dev.render();
```

. We can ignore the unified interface and use both of them at the same time.
Currently there are only two possible renderers, we can do something like this

```
bool ok = false;
#if SVG_ENABLED
if(format == "svg") {
svg_renderer->render();
ok = svg_renderer->ok();
}
#endif
if(!ok)
   bmp_renderer->render();
```

Might need more checking in practice.

Here are some other ways of doing this

:one:We can mix rendering of text and images, and let the browser handle it. For example

``` html
<div> text1 </div>
<img> image 1</img>
<div> text2 </div>
<img> image 2</img>
```

. Hi @josch , thank you very much for your patches! 

I picked a few patches, and added you into the `AUTHORS` file. However it could be easier for us to discuss if you created pull requests.

I'd like to explain a few of them I didn't apply:

`use-rsvg` and the png files: right, technically speaking the svg files are source files and png files are generated from them. But these are logo files, which are unlikely to be changed in the future. I just included the svg file and the script for my (and possibly others') convenience. So I don't think it's that necessary to generate png after installation. Another consideration is that I want the png to be official, what if users generate different png files?

`pdf.js`: `compatibility.js` is indeed from PDF.js, but I removed something from it that are not necessary here. I think it's better to keep this copy to make sure that it's always compatible with pdf2htmlEX.

`closure` vs `yui-compressor`: it might look weird since I'm including both of them. But closure seemed to be better than yui-compressor on JS, yet it cannot handle CSS. So I'm using closure for JS and yui for CSS. 

`unused js file`: some supporting JS files are minimized before included in the output html file. But in HTML, it's very likely that the user want to examine the content, or to make changes, which cannot be done on minimized files. That's why I'm shipping those original source files even if they appear not to be used. Especially since the files might be changing time to time, it'll be painful for the users to find the files if not shipped in the first place.

. What's a 'token'?
I feel it is not that easy to read this way, generally I saw

```
#if DEBUG
   do something
#endif
```

or

```
DEBUG_PRINT("%s\n", something)
```

But your `DT_DEBUG` looks like a function, but it's not. Could be less readable than #if/#endif
. Not sure if minimizing token would have any advantages for us.

About 'mimic a function', it's for readability, the macro you defined looks like a function, but does something quite different than it appears. 

For example

```
DEBUG(int i);
.. something else ...
DEBUG(cout << i);
```

It's not obvious that DEBUG(int i) defines a local variable in the scope, and the lines are harder to read -- unless the reader find the definition of DEBUG

On the other hand, for the `#if DEBUG` and `DEBUG_PRINT` cases, I bet most reader can understand it just as normal statements.

Another reason would be, it hurts syntax highlighting.

Hope that it makes sense to you.
. Oh, if those macros are only for your own debug purpose, probably you should not leave them there. I thought you might ask people to enable them and show you the message for diagnosis.
. In that case, I think readability is more important, that's why we put so
much efforts in comments and coding styles when we share code. What do you
think?

. I think that just hurts readability too much. 

Actually I haven't noticed the printf inside until you use this multi-line versison. I guess DEBUG_PRINTF is enough for most cases, and elsewhere you could use #if. When would do you a single-line `DEBUG(...)` that is not printing something?

Also I've been thinking, if you want the messages from the users, maybe it makes more sense to make it a runtime option, either go directly with `--debug`, or using a mask for DrawTracer. Many users are actually using the binary directly.
. By `DEBUG_PRINTF` I mean something like this

```
#define debug_printf(...) fprintf (stderr, __VA_ARGS__)
```

Do you think a function is better than this form?
But indeed you are right about `cerr`, not sure how to do that with a macro.

I was just thinking about creating a 'unified' function for debug messages and discourage the usage of single_line macros.

Also I think a macro for multi-line statements would also be a good switch for `debug_printf`, or your `DT_DEBUG`, could be better than switching comments.

Usually for multi-line debug stuffs, I'd also enclose them with a scope, just to make sure that the local variable won't pollute the outside:

```
#if DT_DEBUG
{
  int i;
  do something with i;
  cerr << i;
}
#endif
```

My recommendation would be, it's fine if you want to stick with `DT_DEBUG`, but never use it with multiple lines, especially do not define local variables there.
Instead, use another macro, say `DRAWTRACER_DEBUG` for multi-line stuffs, and either enclose the content with a scope, or use special names to make sure that it won't affect other parts.
Also `DRAWTRACER_DEBUG` could be a switch of `DT_DEBUG`, and actually why not use a shorter name for `DT_DEBUG`? say `D`?
. It could be like this

```
#define LOG(msg) if(GLOBAL_LOG_MASK & THIS_LOG_MASK) printf(msg)
```

Then we define `THIS_LOG_MASK` in each .cpp file.

Or more easily, we can define `ENABLE_LOG` for each cpp file we want to enable log, somewhat like `assert`

. @duanyao OK, I can reproduce it now. The `inline-block` rule is not only for whitespaces, but also for negative offsets, e.g.

```
<span>Hello <span style="margin-left:-10px">World!</span></span>
```

I remember that without this rule, Things after `World` are not positioned correctly.
. @duanyao It was for negative shifts, e.g. http://jsfiddle.net/v19q42nh/2/
Basically after a negative shift, we want following letters to be place directly after the shift.

If it's getting overridden, it looks like a bug. 
. Yes I did actually.
But what shall we use without it?
. @duanyao I see, and I remember that there is code for this: we don't close a `span` tag if it starts with negative margin until the end of the line. So instead of
`<span style="margin-left:-1em">Text</span><span class="class">Other text</span>`
we do
`<span style="margin-left:-1em">Text<span class="class">Other text</span></span>`

So probably we can modify the default style for `span` for now, and in the future we add more test cases to verify.

According to my experience, there are more issues in the ToUnicode mappings, especially for old PDF files. 

Seems that old PDF generators/converters were not able to handle this well -- after all this has nothing to do with printing. And ToUnicode is indeed optional in the standard.

I'm not sure if this is a good solution. Or possible we can take consideration of the `--to-unicode` parameter, that whether we trust the mapping.

. The design of the hierarchy structures is toward the HTML output, but not according to the PDF instructions. If the design does not reflect that, maybe something is still wrong with the design. In case you were mentioning the behavior of `TextPageBuilder`, it is supposed to convert/adapt the PDF instructions to our structures in an intuitive and fast way, such that we can start working on the structures as soon as possible. 

Yes I've been thinking about to continue using the flatten char array, just like the current design. But the problem I found is that we need to maintain lots of conditions manually. For example, if a `char` is removed (due to hidden by an image, or we decide to covert it to an offset), we need to find the `word` containing it and modify it accordingly. Then I was thinking, if we have to maintain this relationship of belonging, why don't we make it so in the structure and design API functions accordingly? This should be easier for others to understand and extend it, and potentially there could be fewer bugs.

Maybe you are right about most passes are char-wised, yet we may provide a char_iterator for `TextSegment`. The overhead should be small. In fact I had also considered the design of storing all the `char`'s in a list, and defining `TextWord`'s with two iterators, but in the end I thought that the benefit of iterating characters is not worth sacrificing a better set of APIs. At least we could write something like this:

```
for (auto & word : segment) {
  for (auto & c : word) {
    // do stuffs
  }
}
```

And about `vector` vs `list`. In the current design we are using indices as iterators, because `vector`'s iterators may be invalidated in lots of situations, and I found it ugly and error-prone to write code this way. There should less problems with `list`. And yes of course, we can always build a new array for each pass, but who is responsible to maintain the states, API designers or users? In the former case, I believe that the API could be complicated, and in the latter case (API designers can also be users here), the problem comes back again: the users have to carefully maintain the conditions while implementing the algorithm.

Generally I think for flatten-or-not, vector-or-list, both cases are equivalent in theory, but I would like to ease the process of implementing the passes on top of it.
. OK, that sounds good to me. So we do not restrict that the same structure is used in each pass, which makes sense here.

But during the offset<->space convertion, it is possible that we add more offsets in between in order to connect words. Of course we can do so by building a new array, but I'm thinking if it will be easy to do so.

Another problem is, right after we build `TextWord`, we need to make sure that the char array will never be modified, I'm not sure if this constraint is too strong. 

`std::list` or intrusive list may be used to solve both problems, I wonder if there are anything we need from `vector`?

I think that it's not easy to do so, for example, supposed that we have two words "Hello World", which are drawn on the canvas with different matrices (I've seen PDF files which moves to positions by changing CTM). It is possible to check that the `o` and `W` may be connected by normalizing the matrices and then adding an offset in between.

However changing the styles on the char array might not be a good idea, usually style is used for one or more words, and I find it more natural to perform matrix-normalizing pass on the word array.

Currently the plan is to add 'shift_after_x' and 'shift_after_y' for each `Char` and `Word`. What're the benefits of Shift/Offset nodes over this design?
. > There are quite a few chances that normal chars and offsets are converted to each other or even merged. E.g. illegal chars may be converted to offsets and further merged with surrounding offsets/whitespaces. So I think is would be convenient that both normal chars and offsets are represented by CharNode so the convertion/merging can be done in-place.

We may convert chars to offsets, but when shall we covert offsets to chars?

> As to styles, I think TextStyle can be made immutable. If we want to change a CharNode's style, we usually push a new TextStyle object into the per-page array of TextStyle, and modify the CharNode's style pointer to point to the new TextStyle. Unused TextStyles are not reclaimed until end of the renderring of the page, but this should not be a big problem.

By modifying styles, usually I meant re-scaling the matrix as well as the font size, or tweaking the positions, and most of time this happens word-wise. While you can covert style for individual chars, we will get lots of new duplicated styles, which is in my mind not natural or elegant.

An example of changing the styles: [...] & fs denote the CTM and font size
- [2,0,0,2,0,0] & 1 -> [1,0,0,1,0,0] & 2
  So a ID matrix with font_size 2 is more natural than the former case, but there are lots of PDF doing the former way. In the old design, as well as the new one in my mind, whenever we change a style in this way, we should update all the elements using this style, instead of creating new styles for each of them. So the current design of `Segment` acts like a use-list for the style.

I'm considering removing the addition `shift` field in `Char`, leaving it only in `Word`. So `char->offset` means breaking a `Word` into two, and `offset->char` means merging two `Word`'s into one. How's that to you?

With this semantic, there could be even no need to actually merge the offsets in the char-array. We may simply do that in the word-array. In this way the char-array remain the same (but the individual chars may be modified). I really prefer iterators to indices.

About `Word`s, they may be allocated in buffers, but I think (intrusive) list might be better here as they are meant to be split or merged frequently.

. Right now there's `--data-dir` option, but an option to specify manifest filename sounds good.
. I remember that SVG fonts was introduced for Safari series (desktop & mobile) which are still supported now. Maybe we can remove it once it triggers more problem. There's not much effort to maintain it (as long as Fontforge supports it)

Regarding outputting multiple font formats, it's been an old issue #83, but seems that nobody's interested in implementing it.

SVG+CSS, yes, I've been thinking about it. Especially the motivations was to support vector graphics better, and also provided correct overlapping among text and image. (Therefore we won't need `--text-visibility` as for png backgrounds). 

But mixing text and images turns out to be quite complicated. The SVG output is done by the `CairoOutputDev` from poppler. The files are not exposed in poppler as API so they are copied here and synced periodically. Once I tried to make an SVG+CSS output, but I didn't find a solution to inject font rules via cairo, which is the SVG library used. I haven't investigate since them. Maybe things have gone better now, or maybe not.

Regarding `CairoOutputDev` itself, it's painful to make any modifications here, as we will need to make it sync with poppler, which changes their internal APIs often. Yet I'm not sure if they will accept any modifications to make it SVG+CSS, hope so, if not we may need to fork CairoOutputDev ourselves.

Overall I definitely agree that SVG+CSS is a good idea, just hope some one would have the motivation and energy to work on it.

``` diff
diff --git a/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc b/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc
index cf568b2..96e58ea 100644
--- a/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc
+++ b/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc
@@ -111,7 +111,7 @@ void prepare_directories()

     errno = 0;

-    unique_ptr<char> pBuf(new char[tmp_dir.size() + 1]);
+    unique_ptr<char[]> pBuf(new char[tmp_dir.size() + 1]);
     strcpy(pBuf.get(), tmp_dir.c_str());
     auto p = mkdtemp(pBuf.get());
     if(p == nullptr)
```

. Hi @iapain 
In the latest devv branch, I've change the default behaviour when --tounicode=0
Basically when **--tounicode=1**, the ToUnicode Map will be forced applied, when **--tounicode=-1**, the map will be completely ignored.

When **--tounicode=0**, the map is attempted to be applied. If anything wrong is found, it'll be dropped.

I changed the behaviour because I have received many PDF files where there are Type 1 fonts embedded without proper font names in the font, whereas proper ToUnicode CMaps are provided. These are actually more consistent with the PDF Standard.

What do you say about it?

. Thanks for reporting, but please open a new issue instead of simply leaving message here.

pdf2htmlEX is a converter, it always follows the original content in PDF. So if you see spaces among letter, that would means there ARE spaces in the PDF. And it's not possible for pdf2htmlEX to recognize the words.

About zooming, indeed there are problems for different browsers, the problem should not be with the spaces, but font sizes. The browser may round the font size, such that letter will be larger or smaller than they should be. To check if it's the problem you saw, just zoom in, when the letters are large enough, there should never be any problem with font sizes (and thus spaces). 

Currently I don't have any solutions to this, but you may want to check the manpage about the --font-size-multiplier parameter.
. Can you point out the location of the word 'arbeitsmarkt' in the PDF? or
show me a pdf with only that word. I want to compare the visuals.

I didn't mean ' ' either, but consider this:

In PDF, almost everything is absolutely positioned. For the word apple,
suppose all letter are of width 10px, in PDF, the following two operations
should be the same

(1) write 'apple' at (0,0) with font size 10px
(2) write 'app' at (0,0) and 'le' at (30,0), both with font size 10px

and there is no ' '

(2) actually often appears in PDF, I don't know why but it's the truth.

pdf2htmlEX cannot and will not recognize the word 'apple' in (2), and will
generate the HTML code you saw.

The problems when you zoom out, say 33%, idealy (2) should become
(2) write 'app' at (0,0) and 'le' at (10,0), with font size 3.33px.
But the browser may not be happy with '3.33px', it may use '3px' or '3.5px'
or something else, such that the letters may overlapped or be separated.

Also notice that there is no ' ' inside the <span> tag except for the last
one, which is correct.

. Why do you remove those js code?
They are not equivalent.
The js code loads the pages one by one asynchronously,
which prevents page rendering blocks UI events.
. With that line of CSS, the browser will still try to redraw everything
before it can response user's actions.

So when the browser loads all the pages gradually, it'll test if the new
node should be drawn.
With your CSS, still all nodes are drawn as soon as they are loaded,
meanwhile you can get no response of actions like scrolling, so the users
may feel stuck.

But with my CSS, all pages are hidden at first, so the browser knows that
there's nothing to draw at the beginning.
The JS tell the browser to set 'display:block' for each page, and the key
point is that it's done with setTimeOut, which is just a new event. And the
event is in the same queue as UI events (scrolling etc.) So user actions
can be responed before next pages are revealed.

. So fontforge may built with or without spiro.
And pdf2htmlEX should be built in the same envrionment.

There's a macro _NO_LIBSPIRO defined (or not, if your fontforge was built
with spiro), and it affects header files like spinefont.h

According to your cmake log, config.h should be found, which should be in
the same folder as fontforge.h

One possible situation is that fontforge was built with spiro, but you
didn't install the headers of libspiro.
But everything should be fine if you compiled fontforge yourself.

. @deathlord87 What do you mean by UI? 

pdf2htmlEX should extract and provide enough information from the PDF file, such that UI interface can be implemented on top of it, for example, zoom/link/outline/thumbnails etc. pdf2htmlEX should provide no UI, because I assume that publisher is likely to design their own UI theme in order to to match their websites.

However there should be a demo UI, such that others may understand the structure of generated HTML better, you can actually find javascript script code in the repo. Currently what it does are:
- hide necessary pages ( set display:none )
- handle internal link jumps
- handle zoom in/out (disabled currently)

what's- missing for a demo UI include
- UI elements
  - buttons
  - navbar
- corresponding functions for UI elements above for the Viewer object
- effects

In principle, the Viewer object should be out-of-the-box providing necessary function, and UI designers may directly use them.

I suggest jQuery, because it's being used in the repo. Also there's a mobile version.

However as pdf2htmlEX is for general platforms, so I don't suggest use a mobile version directly.

On Tuesday, February 5, 2013, purem wrote:

> Lets look at this statistically
> 
> Total percent of users using a browser with
> some support for @font-face: 93.09%
> support for WOFF 76.61% (17% of users with some support excluded)
> support for TTF 66.47% full, 16.03% partial -> 82.5% total (11% of users
> with some support excluded totally, 27% with support))
> 
> Summary stats
> Best for IE -> EOT
> Best for firefox -> TTF/OTF
> Best for Chrome -> SVG/TTF/OTF
> Best for Safari -> TTF/OTF
> Best for Opera -> SVG
> Best for iOS Safari -> SVG
> Best for android -> TTF
> Best for blackberry -> TTF/OTF / SVG
> Best for opera mobile -> TTF/OTF/SVG
> Best for chrome for android -> TTF/OTF/SVG
> Best for firefox -> TTF/OTF/WOFF
> 
> Comments
> To support anything before IE 9 you need to use EOT. IE only has partial
> support of TTF with @font-face.
> To support old versions of iOS safari and opera you need SVG
> TTF/OTF seems to trump WOFF in terms of compatability in all respects
> however the smaller file size of WOFF is obviously prefered.
> 
> Stats from:
> http://caniuse.com/fontface
> http://caniuse.com/woff
> http://caniuse.com/ttf
> http://caniuse.com/svg-fonts
> http://caniuse.com/eot
> 
> To remedy this we can write fonts in all formats and then either:
> 
> A.) Use multiple font-face formats in the declaration. Font squirrel
> http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fontface/generator recommends the following
> as its "optimal" layout, "Recommended settings for performance and speed.".
> Its recommended by Paul Irish who knows his stuff and has done a long blog
> post on the ins and outs of @font-face declarations
> http://paulirish.com/2009/bulletproof-font-face-implementation-syntax/
> 
> @font-face {
> font-family: 'pragmataproregular';
> src: url('pragmatapro-webfont.eot');
> src: url('pragmatapro-webfont.eot?#iefix') format('embedded-opentype'),
> url('pragmatapro-webfont.woff') format('woff'),
> url('pragmatapro-webfont.ttf') format('truetype'),
> url('pragmatapro-webfont.svg#pragmataproregular') format('svg');
> font-weight: normal;
> font-style: normal;
> 
> }
> 
> Quick Explaination
> The first declaration is for IE9 / IE10 as EOT is the prefered font (IEs
> format so supposdely it does a good job at it).
> The second for IE8 and below. It will take the last src: statement as the
> one to use. IE8 and below have a bug in their parsers which results in 404s
> when more than one font is included in a src declaration. The ?#iefix
> tricks it into thinking everything after the ? is a query string and so it
> skips the other font formats.
> 
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8050640/how-does-iefix-solve-web-fonts-loading-in-ie6-ie8
> The woff, ttf and svg fonts are read by the rest of the browsers if they
> can read them (see above for importance of all types if maximising
> compatability).
> All browsers should only load one font so bandwidth really isn't an issue.
> 
> B.)
> If they do, we could take the aproach that scribd takes and detect
> browsers before injecting a css file containing the fonts in the most
> relevant format. This would require writing a separate css file for each
> font type which contains all required fonts.
> 
> Neither are too hard to implement and will result in increased support. I
> propose that we make A. the default as this version doesn't require JS.
>

. Hello, I've been busy with my own research for the past weeks, and just came back now.

Like @iapain said, I think pdftohtml or pdftotext might be the best choice for you, for now. 

I'm not sure what you want CSS removed, because even those are gone, still you cannot edit the HTML file generated (easily).

Things prevent easy editing include:
- The space padding between words, because in many PDF there are spaces of variant lengths.
- The lines are not reflowable, so if you change the length of a line, it will look ugly
- Fonts, often only necessary glyphs are embedded in PDF files, so if you introduce new characters, they won't show up correctly
  
  And the solutions to each of them:
- To remove the padding spaces with space characters, at the cost of alignment
- Reflowable text, I've tried once, but it's not only an issue of position, but also things like spelling, e.g. sometimes the dash at the end of a line should be removed in order to connect with the next line
- If the PDF file provides with a valid semantic encoding, you can easily substitute the font as you wish; otherwise I think you have to fix it manually.

The essential issue is that PDF has been designed for publishing, not editing.
. I'm going to try to implement the first two soon, and the third one is 'automatically' if there's a valid encoding.
. @404pnf Thanks for your explanation.

Converting pdf to html with corresponding tags would be quite difficult and annoying for me to do, as a hobby. That'd be recognition rather than conversion.

For example

table: to recognize aligned columns, as well as borders
li: not sure about this, maybe to recognize bullet?
h1/h2... : several rules based on the position and font sizes

To me, maybe h1/h2 would be the most difficult thing to do, because I cannot make a formula that works for all the PDF, the rules should be adaptive and adjustable, which might lead to lots of more options. I guess Acrobat does it well because it has lots of samples, and years of adjustment.

I remembered that pdftohtml can also export to xml, but didn't try it.

For now my concern is to output an html with reflowable and editable, making a small step towards structure-oriented html than visual-oriented.
. Indeed, Acrobat should have been guessing, but with more confidence with their well tuned heuristics

I'll implement unwarping lines, there have been a few people asking about editing the HTML, and publishers like @iapain also needs it. But it will be at the cost of losing some visual accuracy.

About file size, PDF supports in-file compression, while HTML does not, so it's not fair. But you can enable deflate on your http server. If you gzip the HTML file, most of time the file size is comparable with the original PDF.

Comparing with PDF.js. pdf2htmlEX started as a toy, as an alternate to PDF.js when a friend of mine needed to display PDF online. The problem with PDF.js (for now) is the slowness, and text handling. The advantage of pdf2htmlEX is all conversion/optimization is done background on the servers, which is done only once, such that they are not imposed on the users -- but seems that PDF.js will do a server-side version.

In short, pdf2htmlEX is for publishers, and PDF.js is for viewers.

The purpose of pdf2htmlEX is to provide a choice, for those who intended to publish in HTML, but was forced to PDF because the lack of tools. Also HTML, together with CSS and Javascript, allows better integration with your web site (themes, links etc), and more creative works --  how about google analytics embedded in your CV online? 

If you would like to help pdf2htmlEX, thank you and here are a few possibilities that you don't have to code.
- Just use it and report bugs.
- Credit it on your sites such that others would be aware of pdf2htmlEX
- Make a small donation if there is a commercial organization behind -- I'd suggest you make a feature request meanwhile

. As a start we may make some assumptions and start from the easiest case:

No header, footer, figure, table. And single column of text.

The task is to combine text lines in the same paragraph. We can further extend this to two-column layouts, as text rendering order is usually the same as reading order.

Spacing might be a problem, I think it's hard to preserve the exact spacing (width of letter-space, word-space, space-char), need to relax and estimate them.

The process should be easy if facilitated with manual marking/adjustments.

Ref: http://scribdtech.wordpress.com/2012/02/29/why-zooming-on-mobile-is-broken-and-how-to-fix-it/

Another direction is to tag the PDF in some way, and to utilize tag information in PDF file.

. You got the point.

Yes, for Linux and Mac, they use freetype or something similar, such that
fonts on screen look like the same as printed on papers - thanks to Apple
But Windows, with ClearType, focuses on "readable".

I think the fonts in PDF standards are similar with Linux/Mac, because I
can't quite tell the difference (visually) between a PDF file and a
converted HTML.
It should be so since PDF is a format for printing.

AFAIK Adobe Reader on Windows should render all fonts by itself, but web
browsers will call Windows API for this, by default the effect could be
very bad since most embedded fonts (in PDF) are lack of proper hinting --
the PDF viewer is supposed to handle this.

ttfautohint may add some hinting with freetype, which is currently the best
solution I have found.
I guess the --external-hint-tool is flexible enough for you, you just feed
a executable or script to it, and don't even need --single-html.

If you find a better solution, please tell me.

. No, the fonts are not identified by names, but internal IDs. It's possible
to embed the same font twice, with different IDs.

If you inspect the resources in the PDF files, you should see lots of fonts
with a same name.

About --remove-unused-glyph, an embedded font may contain some glyphs that
are never used in the PDF file, and these glyphs may be removed in order to
reduce the size of the font file.

. I found the reason.

That part of non-Type3 font is one of the default 14 fonts in PDF, which are not embedded and should be provided by the pdf viewer.

By default I'll translate them to proper font names, and the final result will depend on the environment of the viewer's browser, which is "undefined" theoretically, but should be fine most of the time.

You can force embedding fonts chosen by poppler, by specifying --embed-base-font 1, which would increase the size of HTML file. 

Please give a try and see if it helps.

. Thanks a lot for the efforts. 

I've received many complains about it, and I've been thinking it for a long time, but I've got no elegant solution.

Besides the inline comments, here are a few concerns about it.
- About the prefix --dont, or verbs with opposite meanings:
  - It's hard to memorize, unless you support the prefix for all flags, like --enable/disable or --with/without in autoconf.It will be a little bit more confusing while reading the default values, especially squeeze_wide_glyph vs dont_shrink_wide_glyph
  - It's annoying to change the default value, and there might be compatible problems. For example, when I first implemented auto-hint, it's not mature enough and is turned off by default; but later it can be enabled by default, I have to change it to --dont-auto-hint, and all scripts for older versions of pdf2htmlEX will be invalid.
  - There are no such problems with the 0/1 solution, neither for --enable/disable or --with/without as in autoconf
- Coding 
  - I want the parameters names the same as in the struct Param, 
  - Also the orders in Param.h, pdf2htmlEX.cc and manpage should be the same, for easier maintenance.
  - With the lambda hack, how do you make the sure the default values are 0? I don't see an initialization
  - And when you use the lambda hack so often, there should be a new feature in ArgParser.

I've thought a default configuration file, written in unix conf style, or JSON. Users can modify it, or specify command line arguments to override them. But it's too complicated and I'm not well motivated.

Maybe we can discuss about the solution before you going on.

. This issue has nothing to do with space-threshold. It's about font manipulation. If you copy the text out, you should not be able to see extra spaces inserted.

And to me, absolute positioning is much more than "occasional". I did not hear any complaints about `space-threshold`, so I believe the default value works for most PDF files.
. This PDF is kind of special, the reason you need to turn off
`squeeze-wide-glyph` is that the letter "M" is much narrower than it looks
like. If you select the word in the HTML, you may notice the thin highlight
box under "M".

The thin value is the actual width in the font, so if you actually write
"Man" with this font, you will see overlapping between M and a. There is no
overlapping in this PDF because there is position shift between M and a, or
a is absolute positioned. So logically, there is a quite wide gap there,
and inserting a space there is "logically" correct.

On the other hand, I cannot simply measure the gap between the actually
bounding boxes between glyphs, for example the letter 'Q' in the demo page
of pdf2htmlEX named "Typography".

I've just tested this PDF in Adobe Reader X, and I got "M nagement" copying
that word out.
. More info, the width of a glyph is how much you should shift the current
position horizontally before you can put the next glyph. And bounding box
is the actual size of the painted area of that glyph.

. The width of  'M' in the font is half as it looks like. Suppose 'M' looks
like 2mm width, and 'a' is 1mm width.
So for the word "Management", from the font renderer's point of view,
they're 1cm 'M' + 1cm gap + 1cm 'a'. And it should be OK if we insert a
space there.

A larger space-threshold should eat up this space, by design, but also eats
up all other spaces equal or less than this width, so other parts of the
document might be affected.

The main problem is the bad info in the embedded font in this PDF.

In my previous comment (which didn't show up correctly on github), I said "
On the other hand, I cannot simply measure the gap between the actually
bounding boxes between glyphs, for example the letter 'Q' in the demo page
of pdf2htmlEX named "Typography".

I've just tested this PDF in Adobe Reader X, and I got "M nagement" copying
that word out.
"

So hope this makes sense to you.

. In PDF, glyphs are positioned by the origin, so the ascent/descent info in embedded fonts are not useful.

But in HTML, all positioning rely on ascent/descent, so here I retrieve the actual value (instead of the values from the meta data of the embedded fonts in PDF) with Fontforge.

There are 3 sets of ascent/descent (win, os2, typo). When they are not consistent, different browsers may have different behaviors. So in `ffw_metric` I try to unify them.

. In the text coordinate system,  current position (tx,ty) marks the origin of the next character.
Depending on wmode or not, one of `char_dx` and `char_dy` should be 0. (Maybe there are other cases? I'm not 100% sure)
For horizontal text, char_dy is 0, and char_dx is the width of the next char.

Let `A=ascent * font_size` and `B=descent * font_size` (B is usually negative)
The BBox of the next char should be `(tx, ty+B) - (tx+dx, ty+A)`, so we need to test if this box is completely outside the clipping path.

. Sometimes yes. If you have installed poppler, there is a command `pdffonts` available. The first column shows the names.

The names are not reliable. The accuracy of the HTML depends on the metrics of the glyphs and the encoding of the font. There may be two sets of metrics stored in a PDF, one is defined in the embedded font, and the other stored in the font descriptor in PDF. When they are not consistent, the second one should be used, which means the font have to be transformed -- which can not be done by the browser.

Encoding, if you expect a good font at the client side, the text must be encoded in Unicode correctly, which is not reliable either -- there are too many PDF files whose text cannot be copied out correctly.

Since PDF is not designed for Web, actually I don't see these fonts often used in PDF (except for Times), at least in my test cases. You may verify this use `pdffonts`.

So my point is that it might be worth it to do so. But later I may export the embedded names in CSS, such that you may do post-procssing if you wan. And this should be done carefully since malicious code could be injected in this way.

. @vineet89 Found the cause. The PDF maps the normal '-' into a soft hyphen, and the browsers will hide the symbol since the line does not break there. So essentially it's because the PDF provides a bad encoding.

Please update to the latest git version, and use `--to-unicode=-1`, which should fixes the problem.

However I'll need to test with more files, this behaviour may be changed later.
. @vineet89  Did you update your git repo? I can see a correct output here.

Let me briefly explain this:

In PDF there are two set of encodings, one for displaying (such that a PDF viewer can choose the correct glyphs to show), and the other is for text extraction (such that you can get correct text if you copy & paste). But there can be only one set in HTML, and sometimes it is not possible to achieve both visual accuracy and text accuracy (at least for now). 

In the case of this PDF file, the situation is slightly different, but if you select "xx-Nov-2012" and copy them out from a PDF viewer, I guess you don't see the hyphens, and the reason is that those are soft-hyphens, which should not be. This is provided by the '2nd set of encoding', and fortunately the 1st encoding is correct, and `--to-unicode=-1` forces pdf2htmlEX to use that set if possible. (When the 1st set is not even correct, there is no parameter right now, but maybe I can work out one)

For strictly standard compliant well-formed PDFs, you never need to worry about these issues, but in the wild world of PDF, I'm afraid that it might not be possible to find a set of parameters that works for all.

On the other hand, there are some possible hackings 
- Just convert all soft-hyphens into normal hyphens, since this symbol has special meaning in Unicode
- Mark `soft-hyphens` as invalid, just as NBSP

But none of them are perfect solutions, the first one may break the layout when both normal hyphens and soft hyphens appears in the font; and the second still does not give you correct text.

I wonder if I may hear some suggestions from you?
. @vineet89 Currently I decide to mark 'soft hyphen' as invalid, such that by default the HTML is visually correct.
This behaviour might be changed in the future, I hope I can find a better design later.
. @vineet89  The two sets of encodings are stored in the PDF, which can be any mappings. Currently if you add `--debug 1` and `--clean-tmp 0`, you will be able to find both sets of encodings in `/tmp/pdf2htmlEX-xxx`.

I've just tried again, and pdf2htmlEX gives correct output without any parameters. Please let me know if it doesn't work for you.

However I guess that if you copy the text out, still you get the reversed string, the problem is that in PDF the character are indeed placed from left to right. 

For now, at least I want the visual is correct, such that people can read the document.
. I see that a "Hello" word in RTL language (such that you actually want to see "olleH") in placed left to right, char-by-char in PDF, such that it would be "olleH" in a normal (LTR) environment. After all PDF is designed for printing, so this is reasonable. 

However the browser would recognize the Hebrew characters and try to use the "correct" direction, such that it would be reversed again, into "Hello", which is wrong.

The best solution is to recognize the characters and reverse it, such that we can copy the correct text out. But I don't see a simple solution, given the complicated character positioning rules and the possibility of mixed usage of LTR and RTL languages.

. Hi @rcampbell , I just checked this issue again. The causes are:
- Browsers will round the font sizes specified in the page. [ref](http://meyerweb.com/eric/thoughts/2010/02/10/rounding-off/)
  - That's why `--font-size-multiplier` works
- In your PDF, a sentence is cut into two parts, the second part has a clipping path and therefore the two parts cannot be merged. Now due to the problem above, the first part is longer than we expected, so the end of the first part will overlap with the beginning of the second half.

This is indeed an issue of pdf2htmlEX, but probably not a 'bug'. So far I have no good solutions in my mind.

The vertical shift issue might be compensated by a smaller value of `--veps`.

Finally, I wonder why `--space-as-offset` would help, can you please give an example?

. Hi, the warning message is about malformed encoding inside PDF.
There are two sets of encodings in PDF, one for rendering and the other for Unicode, and pdf2thmlEX tries to merge them for HTML, but it is not always possible to do so. 

When `-tounicode` is not specified, pdf2htmlEX would try to ensure the visual correctness by reencoding some glyphs (but they will become garbage text when copied out). However if `--tounicode 1` is specified, the mapping defined in PDF will always be used even if some glyphs will become missing.

Theoretically this issue can be solved by creating extra fonts for the conflicted encoding, which is not worth the time at this moment. But I'll create an issue for that later anyway.

. `--heps` is already a fault tolerance for spaces. There reason that you see so many tags is because they are spaces of different widths, say 1cm, 2cm or 3cm etc. If a standard space is 2cm, and `--heps` is small, then only 2cm spaces will be replaced with a space character; when `--heps` is at least `1cm`, all spaces between 1cm and 3cm will be replaced with a space character.

. Hi @josch , thank you very much for your patches! 

I picked a few patches, and added you into the `AUTHORS` file. However it could be easier for us to discuss if you created pull requests.

I'd like to explain a few of them I didn't apply:

`use-rsvg` and the png files: right, technically speaking the svg files are source files and png files are generated from them. But these are logo files, which are unlikely to be changed in the future. I just included the svg file and the script for my (and possibly others') convenience. So I don't think it's that necessary to generate png after installation. Another consideration is that I want the png to be official, what if users generate different png files?

`pdf.js`: `compatibility.js` is indeed from PDF.js, but I removed something from it that are not necessary here. I think it's better to keep this copy to make sure that it's always compatible with pdf2htmlEX.

`closure` vs `yui-compressor`: it might look weird since I'm including both of them. But closure seemed to be better than yui-compressor on JS, yet it cannot handle CSS. So I'm using closure for JS and yui for CSS. 

`unused js file`: some supporting JS files are minimized before included in the output html file. But in HTML, it's very likely that the user want to examine the content, or to make changes, which cannot be done on minimized files. That's why I'm shipping those original source files even if they appear not to be used. Especially since the files might be changing time to time, it'll be painful for the users to find the files if not shipped in the first place.

. What's a 'token'?
I feel it is not that easy to read this way, generally I saw

```
#if DEBUG
   do something
#endif
```

or

```
DEBUG_PRINT("%s\n", something)
```

But your `DT_DEBUG` looks like a function, but it's not. Could be less readable than #if/#endif
. Not sure if minimizing token would have any advantages for us.

About 'mimic a function', it's for readability, the macro you defined looks like a function, but does something quite different than it appears. 

For example

```
DEBUG(int i);
.. something else ...
DEBUG(cout << i);
```

It's not obvious that DEBUG(int i) defines a local variable in the scope, and the lines are harder to read -- unless the reader find the definition of DEBUG

On the other hand, for the `#if DEBUG` and `DEBUG_PRINT` cases, I bet most reader can understand it just as normal statements.

Another reason would be, it hurts syntax highlighting.

Hope that it makes sense to you.
. Oh, if those macros are only for your own debug purpose, probably you should not leave them there. I thought you might ask people to enable them and show you the message for diagnosis.
. In that case, I think readability is more important, that's why we put so
much efforts in comments and coding styles when we share code. What do you
think?

like this?
. I think that just hurts readability too much. 

Actually I haven't noticed the printf inside until you use this multi-line versison. I guess DEBUG_PRINTF is enough for most cases, and elsewhere you could use #if. When would do you a single-line `DEBUG(...)` that is not printing something?

Also I've been thinking, if you want the messages from the users, maybe it makes more sense to make it a runtime option, either go directly with `--debug`, or using a mask for DrawTracer. Many users are actually using the binary directly.
. By `DEBUG_PRINTF` I mean something like this

```
#define debug_printf(...) fprintf (stderr, __VA_ARGS__)
```

Do you think a function is better than this form?
But indeed you are right about `cerr`, not sure how to do that with a macro.

I was just thinking about creating a 'unified' function for debug messages and discourage the usage of single_line macros.

Also I think a macro for multi-line statements would also be a good switch for `debug_printf`, or your `DT_DEBUG`, could be better than switching comments.

Usually for multi-line debug stuffs, I'd also enclose them with a scope, just to make sure that the local variable won't pollute the outside:

```
#if DT_DEBUG
{
  int i;
  do something with i;
  cerr << i;
}
#endif
```

My recommendation would be, it's fine if you want to stick with `DT_DEBUG`, but never use it with multiple lines, especially do not define local variables there.
Instead, use another macro, say `DRAWTRACER_DEBUG` for multi-line stuffs, and either enclose the content with a scope, or use special names to make sure that it won't affect other parts.
Also `DRAWTRACER_DEBUG` could be a switch of `DT_DEBUG`, and actually why not use a shorter name for `DT_DEBUG`? say `D`?
. It could be like this

```
#define LOG(msg) if(GLOBAL_LOG_MASK & THIS_LOG_MASK) printf(msg)
```

Then we define `THIS_LOG_MASK` in each .cpp file.

Or more easily, we can define `ENABLE_LOG` for each cpp file we want to enable log, somewhat like `assert`

. @duanyao OK, I can reproduce it now. The `inline-block` rule is not only for whitespaces, but also for negative offsets, e.g.

```
<span>Hello <span style="margin-left:-10px">World!</span></span>
```

I remember that without this rule, Things after `World` are not positioned correctly.
. @duanyao It was for negative shifts, e.g. http://jsfiddle.net/v19q42nh/2/
Basically after a negative shift, we want following letters to be place directly after the shift.

If it's getting overridden, it looks like a bug. 
. Yes I did actually.

. @duanyao I see, and I remember that there is code for this: we don't close a `span` tag if it starts with negative margin until the end of the line. So instead of
`<span style="margin-left:-1em">Text</span><span class="class">Other text</span>`
we do
`<span style="margin-left:-1em">Text<span class="class">Other text</span></span>`

So probably we can modify the default style for `span` for now, and in the future we add more test cases to verify.

. `--space-as-offset` may not guarantee to work if either the ToUnicode mapping for the font encoding is corrupted.  In fact I had a few test cases before, where the font encoding is OK yet ToUnicode is missing or corrupted. According to my experience, there are more issues in the ToUnicode mappings, especially for old PDF files. 

Seems that old PDF generators/converters were not able to handle this well -- after all this has nothing to do with printing. And ToUnicode is indeed optional in the standard.

I'm not sure if this is a good solution. Or possible we can take consideration of the `--to-unicode` parameter, that whether we trust the mapping.

. The design of the hierarchy structures is toward the HTML output, but not according to the PDF instructions. If the design does not reflect that, maybe something is still wrong with the design. In case you were mentioning the behavior of `TextPageBuilder`, it is supposed to convert/adapt the PDF instructions to our structures in an intuitive and fast way, such that we can start working on the structures as soon as possible. 

Yes I've been thinking about to continue using the flatten char array, just like the current design. But the problem I found is that we need to maintain lots of conditions manually. For example, if a `char` is removed (due to hidden by an image, or we decide to covert it to an offset), we need to find the `word` containing it and modify it accordingly. Then I was thinking, if we have to maintain this relationship of belonging, why don't we make it so in the structure and design API functions accordingly? This should be easier for others to understand and extend it, and potentially there could be fewer bugs.

Maybe you are right about most passes are char-wised, yet we may provide a char_iterator for `TextSegment`. The overhead should be small. In fact I had also considered the design of storing all the `char`'s in a list, and defining `TextWord`'s with two iterators, but in the end I thought that the benefit of iterating characters is not worth sacrificing a better set of APIs. At least we could write something like this:

```
for (auto & word : segment) {
  for (auto & c : word) {
    // do stuffs
  }
}
```

And about `vector` vs `list`. In the current design we are using indices as iterators, because `vector`'s iterators may be invalidated in lots of situations, and I found it ugly and error-prone to write code this way. There should less problems with `list`. And yes of course, we can always build a new array for each pass, but who is responsible to maintain the states, API designers or users? In the former case, I believe that the API could be complicated, and in the latter case (API designers can also be users here), the problem comes back again: the users have to carefully maintain the conditions while implementing the algorithm.

Generally I think for flatten-or-not, vector-or-list, both cases are equivalent in theory, but I would like to ease the process of implementing the passes on top of it.
. OK, that sounds good to me. So we do not restrict that the same structure is used in each pass, which makes sense here.

But during the offset<->space convertion, it is possible that we add more offsets in between in order to connect words. Of course we can do so by building a new array, but I'm thinking if it will be easy to do so.

Another problem is, right after we build `TextWord`, we need to make sure that the char array will never be modified, I'm not sure if this constraint is too strong. 

`std::list` or intrusive list may be used to solve both problems, I wonder if there are anything we need from `vector`?
