I think that it's not easy to do so, for example, supposed that we have two words "Hello World", which are drawn on the canvas with different matrices (I've seen PDF files which moves to positions by changing CTM). It is possible to check that the `o` and `W` may be connected by normalizing the matrices and then adding an offset in between.

However changing the styles on the char array might not be a good idea, usually style is used for one or more words, and I find it more natural to perform matrix-normalizing pass on the word array.

Currently the plan is to add 'shift_after_x' and 'shift_after_y' for each `Char` and `Word`. What're the benefits of Shift/Offset nodes over this design?
. > There are quite a few chances that normal chars and offsets are converted to each other or even merged. E.g. illegal chars may be converted to offsets and further merged with surrounding offsets/whitespaces. So I think is would be convenient that both normal chars and offsets are represented by CharNode so the convertion/merging can be done in-place.

We may convert chars to offsets, but when shall we covert offsets to chars?

> As to styles, I think TextStyle can be made immutable. If we want to change a CharNode's style, we usually push a new TextStyle object into the per-page array of TextStyle, and modify the CharNode's style pointer to point to the new TextStyle. Unused TextStyles are not reclaimed until end of the renderring of the page, but this should not be a big problem.

By modifying styles, usually I meant re-scaling the matrix as well as the font size, or tweaking the positions, and most of time this happens word-wise. While you can covert style for individual chars, we will get lots of new duplicated styles, which is in my mind not natural or elegant.

An example of changing the styles: [...] & fs denote the CTM and font size
- [2,0,0,2,0,0] & 1 -> [1,0,0,1,0,0] & 2
  So a ID matrix with font_size 2 is more natural than the former case, but there are lots of PDF doing the former way. In the old design, as well as the new one in my mind, whenever we change a style in this way, we should update all the elements using this style, instead of creating new styles for each of them. So the current design of `Segment` acts like a use-list for the style.

I'm considering removing the addition `shift` field in `Char`, leaving it only in `Word`. So `char->offset` means breaking a `Word` into two, and `offset->char` means merging two `Word`'s into one. How's that to you?

With this semantic, there could be even no need to actually merge the offsets in the char-array. We may simply do that in the word-array. In this way the char-array remain the same (but the individual chars may be modified). I really prefer iterators to indices.

About `Word`s, they may be allocated in buffers, but I think (intrusive) list might be better here as they are meant to be split or merged frequently.

SVG+CSS, yes, I've been thinking about it. Especially the motivations was to support vector graphics better, and also provided correct overlapping among text and image. (Therefore we won't need `--text-visibility` as for png backgrounds). 

But mixing text and images turns out to be quite complicated. The SVG output is done by the `CairoOutputDev` from poppler. The files are not exposed in poppler as API so they are copied here and synced periodically. Once I tried to make an SVG+CSS output, but I didn't find a solution to inject font rules via cairo, which is the SVG library used. I haven't investigate since them. Maybe things have gone better now, or maybe not.

Regarding `CairoOutputDev` itself, it's painful to make any modifications here, as we will need to make it sync with poppler, which changes their internal APIs often. Yet I'm not sure if they will accept any modifications to make it SVG+CSS, hope so, if not we may need to fork CairoOutputDev ourselves.

Overall I definitely agree that SVG+CSS is a good idea, just hope some one would have the motivation and energy to work on it.

diff --git a/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc b/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc
index cf568b2..96e58ea 100644
--- a/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc
+++ b/src/pdf2htmlEX.cc
@@ -111,7 +111,7 @@ void prepare_directories()

     errno = 0;

-    unique_ptr<char> pBuf(new char[tmp_dir.size() + 1]);
+    unique_ptr<char[]> pBuf(new char[tmp_dir.size() + 1]);
     strcpy(pBuf.get(), tmp_dir.c_str());
     auto p = mkdtemp(pBuf.get());
     if(p == nullptr)
```

. Let me go technical for you. CSS `position:absolute` place content anywhere on page provided `left,top,right,bottom` etc. What we're doing in css is defining everything 0 and placing div absolute to 0. My argument is instead of doing this absolute by just placing it to 0,0 and that's what patch provides. First, it reset the co-ordinates and then it place div normally without absolute positioning. Here is an example and it works for me in IE8+, Chrome, FFx, Safari.

[http://dl.dropbox.com/u/75853179/10.1.1.172.6050.html](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/75853179/10.1.1.172.6050.html)
. I know it's not going to work and changes are required to make it work properly. I just wanted to elaborate that using position absolute is not wise for usability and accessibility. It's work is progress and Lu and I totally aware of it. Point is to slowly get rid of absolute from the pdf-main container.

Regarding Mobile devices @coolwanglu problem is not exactly with width and viewports. It's more related to memory optimization in iOS which degrades some features when memory warning is received. There are quite a few tricks to make it more responsive as mentioned here.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9941972/slow-list-view-scrolling-on-ipad-when-scrolling-in-an-overflowauto-div

@deathlord87 Based on my tests on iPad. I have found that scrolling is very laggy, rest all works with proper zoom option.

. @deathlord87 Thanks for your investigation. I think the only way to make work inside Safari is to write your own viewer. pdf2htmlEx does support split output.

Regarding memory leaks, It might be safari bugs. I also tried to optimize and what I out that loading one page one time helps. I am not sure if we should report it to webkit. I need to further investigate about what are the limits and if hardware acceleration helps.

BTW 10+ MB on scrolling is huge, @coolwanglu may it worth exploring flowable text.
. @coolwanglu Flowable text can dramatically ease Safari rendering problems. On the top of that the result output can fit in any screen which is equally important.

I have heard some browsers on Android like Dolphin they enable hardware acceleration by default so that might be the reason why you observed different results.

You can try to trigger hardware acceleration by a 3D transformation in CSS. You may also wants to look at Zapto instead of using jQuery. Zapto is minimal jQuery clone.

. Let me go technical for you. CSS `position:absolute` place content anywhere on page provided `left,top,right,bottom` etc. What we're doing in css is defining everything 0 and placing div absolute to 0. My argument is instead of doing this absolute by just placing it to 0,0 and that's what patch provides. First, it reset the co-ordinates and then it place div normally without absolute positioning. Here is an example and it works for me in IE8+, Chrome, FFx, Safari.

[http://dl.dropbox.com/u/75853179/10.1.1.172.6050.html](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/75853179/10.1.1.172.6050.html)
. I know it's not going to work and changes are required to make it work properly. I just wanted to elaborate that using position absolute is not wise for usability and accessibility. It's work is progress and Lu and I totally aware of it. Point is to slowly get rid of absolute from the pdf-main container.

---

Sent from iPhone

Deepak Thukral
Developer
Fagbokforlaget & VB

> 
> When I modify the manifest file with your changes, then I see the same result as you. However, you've still broken the lazy loading code - pages are supposed to be loaded as they become visible, but the JavaScript code relies on absolute positioning logic. Instead, with you change all pages are immediately visible, which is ok for your test document but will cause degraded performance on longer documents with lots of images. You'll need to update the lazy loading logic in pdf2htmlEX.js to account for non-absolute positioning.

antonywu:
homebrew is not quite the same as MacPorts, because MacPorts will build the entire base dependency from scratch for you, whereas homebrew builds on what Mac comes out of box. It is a different philosophy in package management.
. homebrew is not quite the same as MacPorts, because MacPorts will build the entire base dependency from scratch for you, whereas homebrew builds on what Mac comes out of box. It is a different philosophy in package management.

deathlord87:
@jamiely  I use snow leopard and it works fine when compiled from sources.
. This alone can make this project as a standalone super feature. Most of the pdf2html converters dont support mobile devices and most of mobile devices has inbuilt javascript based rendering mechanism which screws up the UI. It is really a nice to have feature if there's mobile support for the html's like a command line arg-- 

pdf2htmlEx somefile.pdf --ipad
pdf2htmlEx somefile.pdf --iphone3.5inch
pdf2htmlEx somefile.pdf --iphone5 

what do you guys think about this ?
. for presets basically which has ipad/iphone may display html content with no grey space and the page zoomed to the particular size (ipad 1024x768 for landscape and 768x1024 for portrait in viewport setting in meta tag and for iPhone <iPhone 5 will have 320x480 where as iPhone5 will have 640x1136).  

for scrolling iscroll js can be used to make it smoother - http://cubiq.org/iscroll

simple tweaks which make this a better for use on all platforms. I hope i'm making clear of the objective and not deviating.

@coolwanglu  you can use some online simulations like http://quirktools.com/screenfly/ which will help you to view on simulators, its very close to a real device but its never = to a real device.
. yeah I tried --fit-width but the issue arised when turning the device to landscape and portrait mode. The grey spaces will show up when turning the devices.
. the pages when rotating the device must adjust to fit the screen's new width after rotation.
. yes the scrolling is slow only because of the javascript. Try removing the jquery in manifest and run on iPad. Its better than the app with the jquery. i really dont understand what the javascript does. 

About memory warnings. It's beacause of the scrollable div area as I've read. Thats why i suggested iscroll dont know if that will work either, its all about performance. 

@iapain also try compiling the sources with loading the html with the following change in manifest.

<!body>
<!div id="pdf-main">

to 

<!body id="pdf-main">

It loads a bit better. I will run performance tests with instruments in mac and give some ideas of memory peaks.
. Hey everyone, As @iapain as asked i've benchmarked the ios safari and profiled it. The memory peaks as and when we scroll the pages. Safari crashes/freezes when it reaches 14-18MB mark. 

When used in UIWebView (Safari View for app development) it crashes at 10+ MB loaded. The memory needs to be handled efficiently so that the scrolling is not laggy. also the page which is visible + 1 back and +1 forward pages alone should be rendered all the other pages need not be rendered. I think too many <div> elements are the reason for crashing.

Currently when scrolling through the PDF the memory is loaded with the Full PDF and as we scroll the pages on the top is still live in memory, though Its not visible to the user.

I tried with issue65_en.pdf - http://dl.fullcirclemagazine.org/issue65_en.pdf which is loaded as an example. When I reach page 6-10 Its crashing.
. @coolwanglu the 18M is the size of the full HTML, its not necessary for the Devices be it mobile/desktop to eat up 18+ MB's of RAM for just viewing 1 page at a time. 
And yes! ,you are right the purpose of the project is to enable conversion of content, and 8/10 the conversion happens properly thanks to all your effort. There's much more great things that this project is capable of, I am writing a server side code(Node.js/Shell.js) to enable users to upload pdf's and get converted html as downloads, will open a repo soon.
. hey guys, I've written a server on Node/Shell.js for pdf2htmlEX for uploading documents and converting it on the fly. Check out my repo at https://github.com/deathlord87/pdf2htmlEX_server

Soon I shall upload the mobile app which I'm working on.
. will fix some ui this weekend guys. may be secha touch ? what you all suggest ??
. hmmm...!! I just wanted to create a better interface for people to upload thier pdf files and immidiately get their responses as page by page html with prev and next buttons. I'm currently struck as I dont have any idea of client side javascripts/jquery stuff. I am an OO Guy :(

. Hey everyone, As @iapain as asked i've benchmarked the ios safari and profiled it. The memory peaks as and when we scroll the pages. Safari crashes/freezes when it reaches 14-18MB mark. 

When used in UIWebView (Safari View for app development) it crashes at 10+ MB loaded. The memory needs to be handled efficiently so that the scrolling is not laggy. also the page which is visible + 1 back and +1 forward pages alone should be rendered all the other pages need not be rendered. I think too many <div> elements are the reason for crashing.

Currently when scrolling through the PDF the memory is loaded with the Full PDF and as we scroll the pages on the top is still live in memory, though Its not visible to the user.

I tried with issue65_en.pdf - http://dl.fullcirclemagazine.org/issue65_en.pdf which is loaded as an example. When I reach page 6-10 Its crashing.
. @coolwanglu the 18M is the size of the full HTML, its not necessary for the Devices be it mobile/desktop to eat up 18+ MB's of RAM for just viewing 1 page at a time. 
And yes! ,you are right the purpose of the project is to enable conversion of content, and 8/10 the conversion happens properly thanks to all your effort. jahewson:
Hardware acceleration is not a panacea. Mobile devices have a limited memory devoted to the GPU, and once you fill this, performance degrades or the browser crashes. Mixing non-accelerated with accelerated elements can cause rendering problems. Hardware acceleration tends to be to the detriment of font anti-aliasing, but this varies a lot between browsers and platforms. So yes, it's worth looking at, but don't assume you can hardware-accelerate a 10MB+ DOM . There's also the CSS `clip` property which supports a rectangular clipping path, which is widely supported http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/visufx.html#clipping . I have code which discards text which is completely outside the clipping area . I don't do anything fancy with css clip, but this could be added for partially-clipped text. I already approximate the clipping area to a rectangle for visibility checking. I can probably commit the code in the next day or so. On 4 Apr 2013, at 17:02, Lu Wang notifications@github.com wrote: > @jahewson > Yeah, I meant that property actually, both of them have been introduced in html5rocks link > > I've just taken a look at Crocdoc's output of the "typeface" PDF, not surprised by their solution. > > I'm about to work on this issue. You mentioned that you've been working on this one, what's the progress? We may support only rectangles for a start > > — > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub. . > Paging cannot be controlled - the latest CSS standard is not supported by browsers right now, SVG might work for this. SVG won't work for paging. Most browsers support SVG 1.1, which does not include multiple pages. Multiple pages are [part of SVG 1.2 Full](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/WD-SVG12-20041027/multipage.html), however SVG 1.2 Full was abandoned, and replaced by SVG 1.2 Tiny which some browsers support, but it does not include multiple pages. The next version of SVG will be SVG 2.0, at some point in the distant future. . That Firefox bug has "Status: RESOLVED FIXED" since October 2012. Ok I found out why printing is broken in Chrome, it ignores absolute content when deciding the page size. There's a simple fix: **1. delete the following CSS attributes from `#pdf-main`:** ``` css position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; bottom: 0; right: 0; ``` **2. add the declaration:** ``` css body { margin: 0; } ``` Now printing in Chrome will work. It still needs some improvement though... . Looks like CSS has page-breaks http://davidwalsh.name/css-page-breaks . > Does `body {margin:0}` remove the page margin when printing ? No, but this might: ``` css @page { margin: 0; } ``` Ultimately the print margins are decided by the browser, OS, and print driver. . @haisum why not use Yum? . I mean use Yum to install Poppler and FontForge . It's not the usual behaviour of PDF readers to re-scale on a page-by-page basis. I just checked Adobe Acrobat, Chrome, and OSX Preview, and non of them do that. The standard method is "Zoom to Fit" where the entire document is scaled by a single factor. This is the same behaviour as `--fit-width ` provides. @Simanas, `--fit-width` and `--zoom` are mutually exclusive. If you're trying to fit to a given width such as 960px then use `--fit-width`. If you're trying to implement "Zoom to Fit" then you'll need to do that in CSS in the browser. However if you're trying to zoom each page with it's own specific scale, then this is not a standard feature of PDF viewers, as it is _no longer a faithful rendering of the document_. If you want to do that, then I'd recommend pre-processing the PDF via another tool. My vote is that pdf2htmlEX should stick to doing one thing and do it well, and avoid feature creep. . @Simanas a _conversion_ should faithfully reproduce the input, just in a different format. You're wanting to _manipulate_ the output by re-sizing individual pages, which actually means you're breaking the concept of page size. So while re-scaling individual pages may fix your problem, it is fundamentally wrong. You can easily manipulate a PDF file in this manner using other tools, before converting the file with pdf2htmlex. There is no need to change pdf2htmlex to achieve this. If you can achieve your goal by manipulating a PDF file beforehand, then you can see it is not a good candidate feature for pdf2htmlex. There has to be a separation of concerns, there's no point re-implementing functionality which you can get from existing tools . The fact is that PDF is a fixed layout format, and breaking that breaks what a PDF fundamentally is. In a broader context if you're genuinely concerned about content then you shouldn't be using PDFs in the first place! There's nothing to stop you pre-processing your PDFs to mess-up their pages sizes, go for it, it's your call. Use pdf2htmlex as one of many stages in your conversion pipeline, there is no need to add a new feature to pdf2htmlex, for the same reason that pdf2htmlex doesn't need to rotate pages, or crop pages, or do OCR, or support in-browser annotations and generate a new annotated PDF file, or send e-mail. Hardware acceleration is not a panacea. Mobile devices have a limited memory devoted to the GPU, and once you fill this, performance degrades or the browser crashes. Mixing non-accelerated with accelerated elements can cause rendering problems. Hardware acceleration tends to be to the detriment of font anti-aliasing, but this varies a lot between browsers and platforms. So yes, it's worth looking at, but don't assume you can hardware-accelerate a 10MB+ DOM . There's also the CSS `clip` property which supports a rectangular clipping path, which is widely supported http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/visufx.html#clipping . Ok I found out why printing is broken in Chrome, it ignores absolute content when deciding the page size. There's a simple fix: **1. delete the following CSS attributes from `#pdf-main`:** ``` css position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; bottom: 0; right: 0; ``` **2. add the declaration:** ``` css body { margin: 0; } ``` Now printing in Chrome will work. It still needs some improvement though... . Looks like CSS has page-breaks http://davidwalsh.name/css-page-breaks . > Does `body {margin:0}` remove the page margin when printing ? No, but this might: ``` css @page { margin: 0; } ``` Ultimately the print margins are decided by the browser, OS, and print driver. . @haisum why not use Yum? . I mean use Yum to install Poppler and FontForge . It's not the usual behaviour of PDF readers to re-scale on a page-by-page basis. I just checked Adobe Acrobat, Chrome, and OSX Preview, and non of them do that. The standard method is "Zoom to Fit" where the entire document is scaled by a single factor. This is the same behaviour as `--fit-width ` provides. @Simanas, `--fit-width` and `--zoom` are mutually exclusive. If you're trying to fit to a given width such as 960px then use `--fit-width`. If you're trying to implement "Zoom to Fit" then you'll need to do that in CSS in the browser. However if you're trying to zoom each page with it's own specific scale, then this is not a standard feature of PDF viewers, as it is _no longer a faithful rendering of the document_. If you want to do that, then I'd recommend pre-processing the PDF via another tool. My vote is that pdf2htmlEX should stick to doing one thing and do it well, and avoid feature creep. . @Simanas a _conversion_ should faithfully reproduce the input, just in a different format. You're wanting to _manipulate_ the output by re-sizing individual pages, which actually means you're breaking the concept of page size. So while re-scaling individual pages may fix your problem, it is fundamentally wrong. You can easily manipulate a PDF file in this manner using other tools, before converting the file with pdf2htmlex. There is no need to change pdf2htmlex to achieve this. If you can achieve your goal by manipulating a PDF file beforehand, then you can see it is not a good candidate feature for pdf2htmlex. There has to be a separation of concerns, there's no point re-implementing functionality which you can get from existing tools . The fact is that PDF is a fixed layout format, and breaking that breaks what a PDF fundamentally is. In a broader context if you're genuinely concerned about content then you shouldn't be using PDFs in the first place! There's nothing to stop you pre-processing your PDFs to mess-up their pages sizes, go for it, it's your call. Use pdf2htmlex as one of many stages in your conversion pipeline, there is no need to add a new feature to pdf2htmlex, for the same reason that pdf2htmlex doesn't need to rotate pages, or crop pages, or do OCR, or support in-browser annotations and generate a new annotated PDF file, or send e-mail. No its not an IE bug, its a feature. Any font embeded in a PDF is presumably already licensed for embedding. The problem is that bit 2 and bit 3 set embedding only and printing/viewing only which are valid on the context of embeded fonts in a PDF. The purpose of the restrictions is to stop the entire font being reproduced, but pdf2htmlEX is dealing with subsetted fonts, so it's probably not an issue. It my turn out that PDF generators just clear this bit anyway - I've not encountered it. There's a simple workaround - serve WOFF to IE9. . Documentation here http://www.microsoft.com/typography/otspec/os2.htm#fst . **Workaround:** serve WOFF to IE9 via http://www.kltf.de/kltf_notes_ie9ttfembeddingbits.htm. . Ok, but removing`position:absolute` breaks the lazy page loading code in pdf2htmlEX.js. Only the first page is visible in any converted PDF. . Also it completely messes up the **outline**. Did you intend this, or has the change just not been tested? . There's a reason why these elements use absolute positioning - you can't just turn it off and expect things to work. By removing the absolute positioning you've broken the **outline** - this is obviously the only possible impact of the changes you've made... it's what _has_ to happen when you change `absolute` -> `static`. It's got nothing to do with my PDF files. . I figured out why we were seeing different results with multi-page documents **without an outline** - I was applying your CSS change manually via Chrome's inspector, but the lazy loading code in `pdf2htmlEX.js` had already hidden all subsequent pages. When I modify the `manifest` file with your changes, then I see the same result as you. However, you've still broken the lazy loading code - pages are supposed to be loaded _as they are scrolled into view_, but the JavaScript code relies on `absolute` positioning logic. Instead, with your change _all pages are immediately visible_, which is ok for your test document but will cause degraded performance on longer documents with lots of images. You'll need to update the lazy loading logic in `pdf2htmlEX.js` to account for non-`absolute` positioning. None of this affects the **outline**, which is still broken. Have you tried looking at the DOM memory in the Chrome's Task Manager? . > @jahewson what does proportional memory (the last column) mean? @coolwanglu the columns should be: - **Resident:** Amount of memory that is present in physical RAM. - **Shared:** Amount of memory that is present in physical RAM and can be shared with another process. - **Private:** Amount of memory that is present in physical RAM and can not be shared with another process. - **Virtual:** Amount of address space allocated in virtual memory. The most important value is _Resident_, which is the first column. So you're seing a 23% reduction in RAM with your optimizations - great! . No, you are wrong, if user set NR_PAGES_TO_PRERENDER_ON_ZOOM = 0, behavior is like the current and CPU usage is no more than the current.
In that case algorith is like you set: user zoom, all pages are hidden, after a delay they are redrawn (schedule_render).

If user want a more reactive UI, he can set NR_PAGES_TO_PRERENDER_ON_ZOOM to an integer (suggested value 4). In that case when user zoom and pages shown in the viewer are less then 4, the pages are zoomed instantly, without being hidden and redraw after a delay (function schedule_render).

2) css transform on .pd (where w0 and h0 are set) fixing spacing between pages.

Am I right?
. I've already fixed it, take a look at branch zoomfix of https://github.com/micred/pdf2htmlEX

I've also add fit_width/fit_height.
Anyway I've not done a pull request yet because I'm not satisfied with the user experience: zoom works but, as you know, page flickers when zooming because 1) content is hidden, 2) page_frame is resized and 3) the content shown up again.
I've tried to prevent hiding and putting a CSS3 transition to zoom in and zoom out, but looks bad because content (pc) is zoomed smoothly but frame (pf) is not tied to. Here a video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Re0yOcE0h4&feature=youtu.be

I have a suggestion to resolve the problem and give a better user experience but it's needed to add a div and I don't know if you agree.
If we apply CSS transform to page_decoration (pd) we can have a fluid result and without flickering, but we have to add a div for layout (e.g. pl). pl will be parent of pd and will change in height as now is page_decoration (but with overflow:hidden).

What do you think about it?
. eheh, sorry for my english :-) 
As you see in the video, scaling of the frame is not tied to scaling of the content. So if you want to avoid hide-show flickering you see: resize of the frame, resize and reflow of the content separately.
. Yes, I've applied transformation on `pf` but if page border is on `pd` results are not good, because animation is not in sync as I said above. And it's slow due to content reflow when changing `pd` size.
Honestly I've no idea how to do it smoothly without adding a new `<div>`.
I can apply transformation to `pd` but I don't like it because positioning will be mess up.
. ok :-)
let's work to a solution that let's us easily implement 2-pages view or a more advance page layout.

. Sure, give me a couple of days I'm out of town.
. No, you are wrong, if user set NR_PAGES_TO_PRERENDER_ON_ZOOM = 0, behavior is like the current and CPU usage is no more than the current.
In that case algorith is like you set: user zoom, all pages are hidden, after a delay they are redrawn (schedule_render).

If user want a more reactive UI, he can set NR_PAGES_TO_PRERENDER_ON_ZOOM to an integer (suggested value 4). In that case when user zoom and pages shown in the viewer are less then 4, the pages are zoomed instantly, without being hidden and redraw after a delay (function schedule_render).

Which global handlers do you mean? Let me know.

. @coolwanglu Awesome!
. For common fonts, such as Verdana, Arial, Georgia etc., is is possible to skip embedding entirely and just write css such as `font-family: verdana, sans-serif`?
. Is there at least any way to tell the name of the embedded font?
. By common fonts I meant core web fonts, those are very highly likely to be installed on user's machine.
I think the relevant ones are specifically: Arial, Arial Black, Andale Mono, Courier New, Georgia, Impact, Times New Roman, Trebuchet MS, Verdana
. I admire the depth of your knowledge on the subject.
Having a font name, available at least as a clue would be valuable for post processing. PDF files published on government websites almost always use a subset of core web fonts.

Also I am guessing the problem with duplicate fonts the OP is experiencing might be that bold and regular could end up as two embedded fonts. It seems to be the case for my example PDF.
. It seems like the problem is that the background image gets selected instead of the text when doing only single-tap-and-hold. Maybe z-ordering in the CSS can solve this?
. Feel free to sanitize font names with a whitelist of allowed characters `[a-zA-Z0-9_-\+ ]` or even `[a-zA-Z0-9 ]`.
I don't think comments are useless in CSS, it would be easier for post processing code to take hints from a CSS comment closer to the embedded font. `.f1{/* Arial */ @font-face...}`. If log file is easier to implement, that's fine. As long as meta data does not get lost.
. Solved. Don't use the latest version of poppler (poppler-0.24.1). When I switched back to poppler-0.23.4 it built beautifully. Thanks Coolwanglu for a great tool!

Best for firefox -> TTF/OTF
Best for Chrome -> SVG/TTF/OTF
Best for Safari -> TTF/OTF
Best for Opera -> SVG
Best for iOS Safari -> SVG
Best for android -> TTF
Best for blackberry -> TTF/OTF / SVG
Best for opera mobile -> TTF/OTF/SVG
Best for chrome for android -> TTF/OTF/SVG
Best for firefox -> TTF/OTF/WOFF

Comments
To support anything before IE 9 you need to use EOT. IE only has partial support of TTF with @font-face.
To support old versions of iOS safari and opera you need SVG
TTF/OTF seems to trump WOFF in terms of compatability in all respects however the smaller file size of WOFF is obviously prefered.

Stats from:
http://caniuse.com/fontface
http://caniuse.com/woff
http://caniuse.com/ttf
http://caniuse.com/svg-fonts
http://caniuse.com/eot

To remedy this we can write fonts in all formats and then either:

A.) Use multiple font-face formats in the declaration. Font squirrel http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fontface/generator recommends the following as its "optimal" layout, "Recommended settings for performance and speed.". Its recommended by Paul Irish who knows his stuff and has done a long blog post on the ins and outs of @font-face declarations http://paulirish.com/2009/bulletproof-font-face-implementation-syntax/

@font-face {
    font-family: 'pragmataproregular';
    src: url('pragmatapro-webfont.eot');
    src: url('pragmatapro-webfont.eot?#iefix') format('embedded-opentype'),
         url('pragmatapro-webfont.woff') format('woff'),
         url('pragmatapro-webfont.ttf') format('truetype'),
         url('pragmatapro-webfont.svg#pragmataproregular') format('svg');
    font-weight: normal;
    font-style: normal;

}

Quick Explaination
The first declaration is for IE9 / IE10 as EOT is the prefered font (IEs format so supposdely it does a good job at it).
The second for IE8 and below. It will take the last src: statement as the one to use. IE8 and below have a bug in their parsers which results in 404s when more than one font is included in a src declaration. The ?#iefix tricks it into thinking everything after the ? is a query string and so it skips the other font formats.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8050640/how-does-iefix-solve-web-fonts-loading-in-ie6-ie8
The woff, ttf and svg fonts are read by the rest of the browsers if they can read them (see above for importance of all types if maximising compatability).
All browsers should only load one font so bandwidth really isn't an issue. 

B.)
If they do, we could take the aproach that scribd takes and detect browsers before injecting a css file containing the fonts in the most relevant format. This would require writing a separate css file for each font type which contains all required fonts.

Neither are too hard to implement and will result in increased support. I propose that we make A. the default as this version doesn't require JS.
. SVG has best compatibility, its good to have it there just in case. Its minimal effort anyway. 
. I was responding to your post. SVG has best computability for iOS. It doesn't matter that SVG isn't supported in Firefox and IE as they won't be used there!

Supporting more browsers will not be that much work and is a good thing. I'm implementing it now. There aren't any downsides. Whats the problem?

. I have been hacking around with the @font-face generation. I am creating a

. Since I compiled poppler myself, it didn't set environment variable PKG_CONFIG_PATH. So this is how I got it fixed:

```
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig
cmake . -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=/usr/bin/gcc44 -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=/usr/bin/g++44
```

Thanks coolwanglu and iapain for your help :) and great work with this project coolwanglu :+1: 
. Since I installed it successfully on CentOS here are steps I followed for reference of others:
- INSTALL LIBPNG
  ***********\* THIS IS IMPORTANT TO BE INSTALLED FIRST********
  http://sourceforge.net/projects/libpng/files/libpng15/1.5.13/

--if it fails for zlib requirement, install zlib from
http://sourceforge.net/projects/libpng/files/zlib/1.2.7/
- install poppler with xpdf header >= 0.20.0 (compile with --enable-xpdf-headers)
  http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-0.20.5.tar.gz
- install poppler-data
  http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-data-0.4.6.tar.gz
- install fontforge (with header files)
  http://sourceforge.net/projects/fontforge/files/fontforge-source/fontforge_full-20120731-b.tar.bz2/download
- On CentOS if you don't have gcc >= 4.4.6 you can use gcc44. 
  To install gcc44 do 
  `yum install gcc44-c++` or `yum install gcc44*`

Then do 

```
$ export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig
$ cmake . -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=/usr/bin/gcc44 -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=/usr/bin/g++44
########### cmake . is to be run in directory containing source files of pdf2htmlEx###########
$ make
$ make install
```
. can you verify if libfontforge.so exists?
One of these commands should list it:

```
ls /usr/local/lib | grep fontforge
ls /usr/lib | grep fontforge
```
. Yum, in some distros might install older/incompatible versions, but there's no bad in installing it with yum if it works for you.

flyandi: Here is my solution for CentOS .. It's a complete script that will do everything automatically. #!/bin/bash # (deps) echo "Installing Dependencies" yum -y install gcc yum -y install gcc-c++ yum -y install cmake yum -y install libtool yum -y install libpng-devel yum -y install libjpeg-devel yum -y install fontconfig-devel # (tmpdir) echo "Preparing Directory" mkdir -p /tmp/code cd /tmp/code # (resources) echo "Downloading Sources" wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-0.20.5.tar.gz wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-data-0.4.6.tar.gz wget http://sourceforge.net/projects/fontforge/files/fontforge-source/fontforge_full-20120731-b.tar.bz2/download wget https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/archive/v0.10.tar.gz tar xfv poppler-0.20.5.tar.gz tar xfv poppler-data-0.4.6.tar.gz tar jxf fontforge_full-20120731-b.tar.bz2 tar xfv v0.10 # (Installing) echo "Installing" cd poppler-0.20.5 export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig ./configure "--enable-xpdf-headers" make make install cd ../poppler-data-0.4.6 export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig cmake . make make install cd ../fontforge-20120731-b export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig ./configure "--without-libzmq" "--without-x" "--without-iconv" "--disable-python-scripting" "--disable-python-extension" make make install cd ../pdf2htmlEX-0.10 export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig cmake . make make install echo /usr/local/lib > /etc/ld.so.conf.d/local.conf ldconfig . Here is my solution for CentOS .. 404pnf:
These are my use cases, 1. Older books and magazines Bbelieve it not, at least two publishers I work with don't have older books and back issues in source format, only pdf. Most older books only have text. These out-dated books will not likely to be re-published on paper but the publisher would like to have them in a easily reusable electronic format. 2. Transcripts of open course projects from MIT/Yale, etc, mainly text. Lecture notes and transcripts are released in pdf format in English from various schools. Volunteers are translating these documents into their own country language. PDF files are not easy for people to re-edit and collaborate. I take some time every month to convert some pdf to xml/html (acrobat) then to markdown , so people can translate the lecture notes in a text editor and everything can be checked in a version control system, be it git or wikis. I also need to convert some already translated lecture notes but released only in pdf format to markdown so they can be improved. With this way, collaboration is easily achieved and the resulting files can be updated/corrected frequently. Images tags can be converted into html fromat easily, but tables need to be re-edited by hand. . @iapain, Let me answer why some of the other tools don't work (properly). ## pdftohtml The generated html doesn't have a structure / wrong structure. A header in the original pdf is not tagged with H1, lists are not tagged with li. html has embeded styles. By default, generate a single html for each page. ## pdftotext The generated txt, in a single file is very good. But it losts all structures. This is good for converting a pdf novel to text, but not for docs with more structures (header, lists, tables), as lectures often are. ## foxit Convert pdf to html is very slow. It tries to reprensent the orignial pdf look and feel, therefore, much time is "wasting" on those sort of caclulations and the the generated html is bloated, complex, and structures are not properly kept. ## acrobat This is very good by comparision, much unfortunately. Sigh. To export a pdf to xml in acrobat is very fast! Yes, very fast. Most important structure is kept. Headers are H1-H6, lists are
  • , tables are "TABLE", images are "ImageData". Images are saved in a separate img directory. Some strucutres are lost, like footnotes. Many other xml tags are in the document, like "Sect", "LI_Lable", etc. To export a pdf to html in acrobat is painfuly slow! Yes, very slow. The generated html tries to be a faithful representation of the original pdf but the structure is no better than other solutions. Even if it were, it's too slow. My workflow: 1. ask collegues to convert each pdf to xml using acrobat (on windows platform) 2. convert these xml to markdown format by writing a ruby script using regex. 3. edit the markdown file to correct mistakes, and convert the html tables tags to markdown using online html to markdown conversion tools, add footnotes tags, adjust list tags (orderd, unorderd) etc. I am using regex because 1. I don't know how to parse xml, 2. the generated xml is not valid, 3. I only keep a small portion (the real content and it's structure) of the the xml file. Currently, I am using this solution, but I don't like acrobat. Because: 1. it's NOT free software It's very expensive. Meaning even people want to help with the conversion, they can't. Also, because it's non-free, nobody is able to tweak it. 2. it's not scriptable I have yet to see a single person I know use scripts to batch process tasks on windows in real life.     14.23 Government Regulation

    MIT & University of Cambridge

    1

    Outline

  • • Definitions
  • • Perfect Competition and Economic Surplus

Currently, I am using this solution, but I don't like acrobat. Because: 1. it's NOT free software It's very expensive. Meaning even people want to help with the conversion, they can't. Also, because it's non-free, nobody is able to tweak it. 2. it's not scriptable I have yet to see a single person I know use scripts to batch process tasks on windows in real life. I know it can be acheived somehow. . @coolwanglu Thank you for your consideration to implement such a feature. The adobe acrobat can export a pdf to xml. It's very fast and the structures are kept. Both are important. I would like to have something like that. A cleaner output file with less "noise" when it comes to the page content. Here is a sample output ```

    14.23 Government Regulation
    of Industry

    Class 2

    MIT & University of Cambridge

    1

    Outline

  • • Definitions
  • • Perfect Competition and Economic Surplus
    • ``` . To clarify, the above sample output is generated by acrobat by using export pdf to xml. That's good enough! . @coolwanglu, After reading your comments, I would retract this feature request. I tired the -xml option of pdftohtml. It didn't recognized the H1 and other tags. When it comes to header, it's just a regular p with style for bigger font size. Until you said it, I always thought acrobat can output the H1 header correctly because when the author wrote the pdf she used correct tags not because acrobat guessed it right. But it's very likely that you are right. I would watch this project (I am not competent to contribute anything except for sparsely testing), but judging from the first try last week, the output is very good, very similar to the original pdf. The file size is huge though. One last question that is off topic, how do you see things like pdf.js. Do you think pdf2htmlex and pdf.js are striving for the same goal (make viewing pdf in broswer easier)? If not, what's the difference? . Thank you for trying this! .

filodej:
Yes, you are right that the _HTMLRenderer_ vs. _HTMLDevice_ separation I have made does not seem natural (but at least it helped me to better orientate myself in the code ;-)

Regarding to other formats, I was thinking about _XML_ dump (or some other form like _JSON_ or _YAML_ for that matter), or maybe about a direct adapter to other form of interface like for example [this one](https://gist.github.com/4154022).
For example an integration of such interface with [pdfminer](http://www.unixuser.org/~euske/python/pdfminer/index.html) renderer looks like [this](https://gist.github.com/4154054).

When I look at your project more generally, then I can see several layers:
- Separation of features which are supported vs. unsupported natively in the output format ( _BackgroundRenderer_ vs. _HTMLRenderer_ ) - could be made more general based on the actual format capabilities
- General services which can be helpful for several output formats (font embedding, line buffering, collecting styles?? ...) - basically the _BackgroundRenderer_ is another such service aka "rasterizer"
- Code specific to a particular output format ( _HTML_ / _CSS_ code generation, ...) - but even in this case - there are many flavors

To me it would be nice to be able to see the layers above more pronounced in the source code, but I totally agree that the code I have pushed did not make the split correctly and so did more harm than good.

Would you mind if I come up with one more attempt after some time when I better understand what is HTML specific and what not? Maybe my second attempt shuld be more conservative and try to cut out general features to a shared place (like in case of _TmpFiles_ ) instead of splitting the _HTMLRenderer_ to two parts (like in case of unfortunate _HTMLDevice_ ).

Kind regards,
Filodej

(edit)
P.S:
I see your argument about direct relation to the poppler's _OutputDev_ interface.
If the majority of your services is HTML/CSS specific then it is better to implement direct adapter instead of trying to 'generalize' the _HTMLRenderer_.

Thank you for your time.
. Sorry, wanted to close the comment and closed the whole request instead...

. I have reverted the three commits we agree are not applicable and pushed one more trying to simplify the CSS style install/export. Feel free to reject it if you do not see it applicable.
. OK then. I'll continue studying the code and consider using the poppler interface directly.
Thank you for your time.
Have a nice day!

. Say we have a pdf document in which the first page is 30 cm wide, all other pages are only 15 cm wide. This is a common case when some of the pages in pdf documment are flipped in 90 degrees.
We want to convert this document in to one html document where every page is exactly 960px wide. Now if I we set --fit-width to 960 (typical web page width) only pages that are 30cm wide will be 960px and the rest ones will be 430px wide. So --fit-width-every feature should fit every page in pdf document to desired width when conversion performed.
I have looked a little bit to the code and noticed that you are calculating zoom factor for entire document. In this case zoom factor should be calculated for every page to fit desired width/height.

alvis:
For text reflowing, you may consider the approach of K2pdfopt. It is an open-source tool which convert pdf file into different page size with reflowed text.

http://www.willus.com/k2pdfopt
. An indian PDF converter (Aiox) seems to be able to convert document to ePub perfectly (with OCR & some manual input). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qC1hwJ8KFL8

Infty reader is even able to convert math equation to LaTex/MathML format.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PHDZEjwWjx0
http://www.inftyproject.org/en/demo.html#0002

Unfortunately, both of them are proprietary. Sources are hence unavailable.
Yet, at least technically speaking, complete reflowing (even with math & table) is achievable.
Also, both of them use OCR as input. It help to identify the relationship between texts.

jmbowman:
A PDF file can have multiple layers, and layers containing images and text can be intermixed.  I've attached a screenshot of a PDF and the output pdf2htmlEX currently generates that shows a more general example of the problem (look at the stack of receipts).

PDF: https://dl.dropbox.com/u/4804331/Layers_PDF.png
HTML: https://dl.dropbox.com/u/4804331/Layers_HTML.png

Other than that, it did a remarkably good job of replicating that page.
. Here's that one page of the PDF for testing: https://dl.dropbox.com/u/4804331/layers_bug.pdf

I think that collapsing all of the image layers into a single image is usually a good optimization, except when it breaks like this.  I guess one solution would be to have options for always collapsing (smallest), always preserving layers (most correct), or only preserving layers for specific pages which you know you'll need it for (best results with extra effort).  Automatically figuring out which pages those are would be nice, but could be a separate improvement.
. One such tool: http://code.google.com/p/ttf2eot/wiki/Demo

Even if there are other showstoppers for supporting older browsers, it'd be nice to see how much of a difference this one change would make; it's the most obvious problem at the moment.  Maybe add a "--legacy-support" parameter which attempts to generate HTML that older browsers can cope with, while leaving it unset still produces clean, simpler HTML5 for newer browsers?  But even in newer browsers, supporting multiple font formats would be useful for the reasons listed above (different sizes, different ones work better in different browsers).  Which font(s) to use depends pretty heavily on your use case, so being able to customize this would be nice.

duanyao:
@coolwanglu 
I have implemented ["covered text handling"](https://github.com/duanyao/pdf2htmlEX/commits/covered_text_handling) initially.
Characters covered by images are detected and (1) are made transparent in text layer, (2) are drawn in background layer.

There are still things to do:
- Fix SplashBackgroundRenderer. The covered text handling requires that text layer is drawn before background, but SplashBackgroundRenderer currently doesn't support this mode, so only svg bg works for now.
- Detect characters covered by paths.
- Handling clip area.
- Speed. The hitting test algorithm is naive, may be slow for complicated pages.
- Merge neighboring transparent chars. Now each char has a `<span>`.
. - The only public interface is `std::vector<bool> & HTMLRenderer::get_chars_covered()`. Optimization could be done in `HTMLRenderer::add_non_char_bbox(double * bbox, int index)` who makes hitting test.
- We have to do char-drawing at least two passes, one for hitting test, one for selective drawing on background. The problem is, how to hint the second pass which chars should be drawn? I don't know a better way than a `chars_covered` array. I'm afraid the data structures used internally in the first pass is irreverent here.
- The Big-O complexity of current algorithm is estimated as O(m*n), m for char count, n for non-char graphics count, if very few chars are covered. Assume each hitting test use 100 CPU cycles, and for a page where m=n=2000, the total time is 0.4G cycles, or 0.2s on a 2GHz core. This is not quite fast, but satisfying me for now, as most of my PDF pages are not that complex. 

Thanks for recommending rtree, I'll take a look at it later.
. Sure. Firstly I want to fix the broken SplashBackgroundRenderer, and this may introduce conflicts with [pending PR 360](https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/pull/360), so I want to do it after #360 it merged.

. These pdf's are produced by acrobat X's optimizer (ghostscript complains about them so no result), so I think it's unlikely that most PDF optimizers would handle this situation. After all, these structures in a pdf don't introduce much bloat.
. @coolwanglu 
Update: I re-tested with ghostscript 9.10, and it does optimize these fonts in my pdf's. After that, pdf2htmlEX will not produce duplicated fonts. However, both acrobat and ghostscript have their limitations.

The dumped jpg files are actually not corrupted, they are in CMYK color space. Unfortunately, it seems most programs can't display them correctly (browsers, GIMP), except 'display' utility in imagemagick. It seems poppler is aware of this issue so it convert these images to png when producing SVG.

Most open source programs use IJG libjpeg to handle jpg. When I test its djpeg utility with the dumped images (`djpeg -bmp -rgb o24.jpg`), it says "Unsupported color conversion request" and fails, so I doubt it support CMYK or not?

So this is arguably a bug in libjpeg or browsers. But If we can't figure out a better solution in short time, I'll workaround this issue by ignoring `--svg-embed-bitmap 0` when non-RGB/gray jpg is encountered. 

By the way, it is better to convert color space of PDF to RGB before feeding to pdf2htmlEX, this not only workaround this issue, but also significantly reduces the output file size (CMYK has 4 channels). You can use acrobat or ghostscript to do this. The command for the latter can be: 
`gs -dNOPAUSE -dBATCH -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -dColorConversionStrategy=/sRGB -sOutputFile=output.pdf input.pdf`
See also https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/wiki/Optimizing-PDF-Files

. Further reach show that PDF does treat CMYK jpeg inverted in contrast to most other programs.

If create a PDF from a CMYK jpeg file by acrobat, the resulting image dictionary has a `/Decode [1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0]` entry, which effectively invert all color components. pdf2htmlEX can dump jpeg in this PDF without problem.

The pdf in this bug report, in contrast, don't have such inverting `/Decode` entries, and the default ones are `[ 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 ]`, which is an identity transform, so the dumped jpegs have inverted color.

On the other hand, if create a PDF from a RGB jpeg file by acrobat, no `/Decode` entry is presented.

However, I can't find the statement in PDF spec saying that "CMYK jpeg(or all format?) should be intercepted in inverted color". Anyone can help?

So we may check the `/Decode` entry before dumping images: for cmyk jpeg, dump only if inverting `/Decode` exists; for rgb jpeg, dump only if no `/Decode` or identity `/Decode` exists.
. @davidhedley 
 Poppler and cairo create the SVG, and most of the work is done by cairo. Poppler provides a hook to allow client code to decide what to do with images inside a PDF. If client code don't want to handle images (`--svg-embed-bitmap 1`), poppler's default behavior is embedding all images into SVG, and convert format if necessary. It seems poppler decides that CMYK jpeg need to be converted (and color-inverted) to png, so the result is correct.
. @davidhedley 
Thanks! It helped a lot.  See also: [JPEG file embedded in PDF (CMYK)](https://forums.adobe.com/thread/975777).

My conclusion is: PDF readers do color conversion incompatibly with most other programs (including browsers): other programs invert CMYK color if 'Adobe' marker (app14) presents in a jpeg file; while PDF readers don't, they solely rely on /Decode array to invert color. 

In your PDF, the CMYK jpegs' color is not inverted, and have no /Decode array. However they have 'Adobe' marker (you can see them by a hex editor), so if they are dumped, browsers will show them in inverted color.

Why 'Adobe' marker triggers color inverting? This is due to an old photoshop bug (according to doc of libjpeg) -- it wrote CMYK jpeg in inverted color (and wrote 'Adobe' marker), and this became a convention (sigh). However, PostScript and PDF decided not to follow this convention (sigh).

Now this issue is fixed by not dumping CMYK jpeg, see #407.

. I think this issue is actually a bug of chrome: it doesn't apply CSS `word-spacing` to the space at the beginning of a line.

If both `--optimize-text` and `--space-as-offset` is on, some lines of your converted html file contain leading spaces, and have non-zero `word-spacing` and `white-space:pre` style, so they are not rendered correctly by chrome. So this issue is not related to `--font-size-multiplier`, but `--optimize-text` and `--space-as-offset`.

Simplified test case (also available [at jsfiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/60dvtceh/)):

``` html
<div style="word-spacing:1em; white-space:pre; border:1px red solid;"> Has leading  space, style="word-spacing:1em; white-space:pre"</div>
<div style="white-space:pre; border:1px red solid;"> Has leading  space, style="white-space:pre"</div>
<div style="border:1px red solid;"> Has leading  space, style=""</div>
```

I tested other browsers, webkit also has this bug, IE11 and firefox work as expected.

According to [CSS spec](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-text/#word-spacing-property):

> Word spacing affects each space (U+0020) and non-breaking space (U+00A0), left in the text after the white space processing rules have been applied.

If `white-space:pre` is applied, leading spaces are "left in the text after the white space processing rules  have been applied", so `word-spacing` should be applied to them too. However, chrome/webkit always give leading spaces normal width regardless of `word-spacing`.

So we may want to report the bug to chrome/webkit (I added [one for chrome](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=404444)). Meanwhile, before browsers have fixed this bug, pdf2htmlEX should avoid generating leading spaces.
. Done ()
. This is a chrome/webkit bug.

A simplified test case (also [here](http://jsfiddle.net/q434vyu6/2/)):

``` html
<style>
#span1:after { /* content:''; */ }
</style>
<div>Any thing here.<span id="span1" style="white-space:pre; word-spacing:-1px; display: inline-block;"> Span1 begins with a space. <span id="span2" style="display: inline-block;">Span2</span></span></div>
```

In chrome/webkit, the `#span2` is wrapped to a next line.

This problem requires quite a few conditions to reproduce:
- one span nested in another span.
- the inner span is the last node of the outer span.
- the 2 spans are both `inline-block`.
- the outer span has `white-space:pre`.
- the outer span's text content starts with a space.
- the outer span's `word-spacing` is negative, no matter how small it is.

If any of above conditions is not satisfied, the problem disappears.

Chrome/webkit actually support negative `word-spacing`, I was wrong with this.

I suspect this bug is a combined effect of 2 chrome/webkit bugs:
1. [ inline-block not honored as white-space:pre's last-child of a line](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=35443)
    Sadly, this bug was reported 4 years ago and still not fixed!
2. [word-spacing doesn't correctly applied to leading spaces](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=404444)

pdf2htmlEX already has workarounds for the 2 bug. For the first one, adds a node to the end of divs:

``` css
.t:after {
  content: '';
}
```

For the second one, pdf2htmlEX avoids put spaces at the beginning of divs.

Unfortunately, none of them cover the nested-span situation.

<del>If change `.t:after` in CSS to `.t:after, .t span:after`, this bug can be workarounded. However, I don't know the performance hit of this method. @coolwanglu, what do you think?</del>

Actually, chrome/webkit also don't apply `word-spacing` to the leading spaces of a `inline-block` span if the `word-spacing` is just specified on that span. So anyway we must also avoid leading spaces in a `inline-block` span which has non-zero `word-spacing`. What a mess!

. Text selection issue in your file is not related to `--correct-text-visibility`, it also occurs without any params.

The problem is: there is a `div.c` near the end of the first page of the generated html, which covers the whole page, so that makes almost all texts unselectable -- except itself.

A `div.c` coresponds to a clip path in PDF file and uses `overflow:hidden` to achieve  a clipping effect. Unfortunately, it has the side effect of blocking user interactions (including seletion) with elements below a `div.c`.

In fact, `--correct-text-visibility` already handles clipping quite well, and should not have such side effect. So can we suppress `div.c` when `--correct-text-visibility` is on? Can we use CSS clipping when `--correct-text-visibility` is off? Or just get rid of  `div.c` completely?

10.6.4 Scan Conversion Rules
...
A shape shall be scan-converted by painting any pixel whose square region intersects the shape, no matter
how small the intersection is. This ensures that no shape ever disappears as a result of unfavourable
placement relative to the device pixel grid, as might happen with other possible scan conversion rules. The
area covered by painted pixels shall always be at least as large as the area of the original shape. This rule
applies both to fill operations and to strokes with nonzero width. Zero-width strokes may be done in an
implementation-defined manner that may include fewer pixels than the rule implies.
...

The 8th char(after `\r`) in PDF is a space, but it is mapped to 'v' in the font's encoding. So when `--space-as-offset` is on, the space is converted to a offset, not 'v'.

According to [the comment in pdf2htmlEX code](https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/blob/67dac7d9934c8092a1698347073ca2045d16c747/src/HTMLRenderer/text.cc#L88-L100), this is a known limitation.

`if(is_space && (param.space_as_offset)  && (uLen == 1) && (u[0] == ' '))`. This seems to bring the 'v' back.

. The problem in the first file (http://djvs.co/Untitleddocument.pdf) is caused by zero width space.

The PDF contains zero width space character (U+200B). This char by definition has zero width, but according to the font dictionary and embeded font file, its width is not zero, but 1 (means same as font size). This is not a problem in PDF, because PDF just treats zero width space as a normal char, i.e. respects the char width defined in the font dictionary or the font file.

But it seems that browsers _always_ display U+200B as zero width, no matter what width is defined in the font file. So in the output html file, characters after U+200B are shifted to left in comparison with the PDF.
I don't know whether this behavior is defined by any web standards, it seems that [CSS Fonts spec](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-fonts/) says nothing about this.

One possible solution is, in `HTMLRenderer::drawString()`, append a offset of the width reported by `GfxFont::getNextChar` if we meet U+200B. However, if the font in pdf maps U+200B to a visible glyph, we still loose it after conversion.
. @coolwanglu it seems not enough to just add ZWSP, it is a long list, see #488.
. It is still unforturnate that all white spaces in this PDF becomes weird private unicodes after conversion. I think maybe we can improve this by checking the glyph before mapping a invalid char: if its glyph does not exist or is empty, map the char to a space, otherwise map it to a private unicode.
. I think this is not a problem, the mapped spaces also have widths assigned, and CSS `word-spacing`s are calculated based on those widths.
. Both normal spaces and zero-width spaces are mapped to normal spaces, if they all have no glyph. Note that in PDF, zero-width spaces are not neccessarily "zero-width", so it is reasonable to convert them to spaces.
. Then some of the spaces will be wrapped in spans, with width assigned.

. After some thought, I think most (if not all) "illegal html unicode without glyph" should be converted to a `<span class="_ _N"> <span>`, because:
- Browsers implement `letter-spacing` for ZWSP etc differently (should not apply, [FF and IE have bugs](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=253143) ), while implement `letter-spacing` for `inline-block` consistently (not apply at all). So converting an illegal unicode to a ZWSP + offset pair is not ideal.
- In order to largely maintain the sematic, most illegal html unicodes should be converted to delimiters (space or something), not just empty spans. P.S. I think if `--space-as-offset` is on, at least one space should also be retained for each converted offset.

In order to accomplish this, `HTMLTextLine::append_offset(double width)` may be extended to `HTMLTextLine::append_offset(double width, Unicode char)`, means a char (in most cases a space) can be assosiated to the offset. This is called "mixed offset"

`HTMLTextLine::text` field can also be extended to type `vector<HTMLTextUnit>`, and `HTMLTextUnit` is defined as:

```
struct HTMLTextUnit
{
  HTMLTextState * state; // or int state, index of HTMLTextLine::states
  int char_count; // corresponding to how many CharCode
  Unicode unicode;
  float width; // width of offset
}
```

Type of `HTMLTextUnit` is implied:
- Normal text: char_count == 1, unicode > 0, width is NaN (means defined by font/state)
- Pure offset:  char_count == 0, unicode == 0, width != 0
- Mixed offset: char_count > 0, unicode == 0x20 (may be extended), width is not NaN
- Repeating spaces: char_count > 1, unicode == 0x20, width is NaN
- Decomposed ligature
  - First: same as normal text
  - Followings: char_count == 0, unicode > 0
- Not in use: char_count == 0, unicode == 0, width == 0

Some notes:
- `char_count` can be used to sync with `CovertTextDetector`
- Pure/mixed offsets may be merged during text optimazition, and `char_count` and `width` are added up. After merging, removed `HTMLTextUnit` can be marked as "not in use" (don't have to compact the vector).
- <del>Large offsets may converted to "repeating spaces" during text optimazition</del><ins>no, this will invalidate char_count. Large offsets may be converted to muliple normal text units.</ins>.
- `HTMLTextLine::offsets` and `HTMLTextLine::decomposed_text` are not needed anymore.
. `DrawingTracer::update_ctm` traces `OutputDev::updateCTM`, and `OutputDev::updateCTM` provides us with the update to the CTM (which should be muliplied with CTM), not the updated CTM. This behavior seems not stated in poppler's document, but you can see `CairoOutputDev::updateCTM`, it is almost the same as `DrawingTracer::update_ctm`.
. Some thoughts:
I think integrating `DrawingTracer` codes into `TextPageBuilder` is feasible, and putting `bbox` into `CharNode` is good.

However, I'd prefer one flatten array of `CharNode` for all chars in each page, rather than multi-level indirection (TextPage/TextSegment/TextWord/CharNode), because:
- Most post processing algorithms (such as text visibility checking, layout analysis) are bottom-up and only care about individual char's properties, so this indirection is not very useful to them.
- TextSegment/TextWord are built according to certain PDF drawing commands, but in many cases this is sub-optimal so we have `--optimize-text`. I believe an advanced optimization algorithm would unlikely rely on PDF drawing commands, and would rather build a new TextSegment/TextWord tree from bottom up by analyzing the array of `CharNode`.

So we can do this:

```
class CharNode
{
  ...
  TextStyle * style; // or int style_index, or merge TextStyle into CharNode
}
class TextPage
{
  vector<CharNode> chars;
  vector<TextStyle> styles;
  vector<TextSegment> segments;
}

TextWord
{
  ...
  int start; // starting index in TextPage::chars
  int end; // ending index in TextPage::chars
}
```

Another question: what's the advantage of `boost::intrusive::list` over `std:vector` ? Inserting/removing nodes seems rather rare, because during post processings we can (and probably prefer to) just build a new tree and drop the old one. P.S. I don't think "all hidden characters should be removed from the structure", because we want to output transparent texts for them (at least for partially visible chars), so setting a flag on invisible `CharNode` should be enough.
. > For example, if a char is removed (due to hidden by an image, or we decide to covert it to an offset), we need to find the word containing it and modify it accordingly. 

Hidden char should not be removed, just marking it as "transparent" should be OK. Because text style is changed, the TextWord containing the hidden char have to be splitted, this seems complicated.

I'd recommend this workflow to avoid such mess:
1. Build an array of CharNode as well as an array of TextStyle while drawing a page.
   -  (Optional)  Run CovertedTextDetector during the drawing, and mark hidden chars in that array. We may push more TextStyles into the TextStyle array and let hidden chars reference them.
2. Do offset <-> space convertion/merging in the array of CharNode (implement offset as a special CharNode). Push more TextStyles if necessary.
3. Iterate over the array of CharNode, and group chars in a same line (according to x/y coordinate) and with same TextStyle into TextWords, put those TextWords into an array. Push more TextStyles if necessary.
4. Iterate over the array of TextWord, and group them into TextSegments, put those TextSegments into an array. Push more TextStyles if necessary.
5. Travel through the tree, generate HTML/CSS codes.
6. Draw background image, and draw hidden chars according to the array of CharNodes.

So we don't have to modify any TextWord/TextSegment/TextStyle but just build them, so iterator invalidation is not an issue.

This workflow is inspired by [PDFMiner](http://www.unixuser.org/~euske/python/pdfminer/index.html)'s layout analysis algoritm (which I had ported to C++).
. > some characters are transparent as defined in PDF, and some are hidden due to overlapping. Shall we show both of them in HTML (transparently)?

We can add a flag to CharNode to distinguish them. However, it is quite hard to tell whether an char covered by an image is meaningless or not. It is also hard to tell whether an char is completely invisible -- what if the covering image is semi-transparent or clipped? So the safest way is to show all covered/clipped chars as transparent.
. > std::list or intrusive list may be used to solve both problems, I wonder if there are anything we need from vector?

Containers in STL are debugger friendly, I can view them in eclipse CDT or VC++, I'm not sure about boost. I'd also prefer index over iterator, because during debugging I always know the progress of a iteration by check the value of the index.

Vector's other advantages are memory alloaction/dellocation speed and less memory fragment, this may be important or not. If the data structure is not quite dynamic, vector is prefered.
. > if we dump all the chars first, we need to store all the styles for each char, the combine them by comparing the styles again

If we store a pointer or index to TextStyle in each CharNode, we can compare the pointer/index first, which should be fast. At least CharNodes generated by a single drawString() call share a same TextStyle object. If we merge TextStyle into CharNode, we can also add a flag inicating "has same style as last char".
. > And about inserting offset to connect words, actually it can be done by adding a field space_after in the class TextWord

I think this can also be done by adding all possible offsets in step 1. If we find some offsets that are not needed when building TextWord/TextSegment, just ignore them.
. I mean we can pre-allocate all possible offsets in step 1, so that don't have to insert offsets when we decide to merge words afterward.
. When a char is to be appended to the CharNode array, unless we are sure that there is no preceding offset (e.g. "e" in "Hello World"), we always append an CharNode with "offset" type before that char (e.g. "W" in "Hello World"). If the width of the offset is yet to be determined, we can assgin 0 to it so that in following steps we can calculate the actual width.

There are quite a few chances that normal chars and offsets are converted to each other or even merged. E.g. illegal chars may be converted to offsets and further merged with surrounding offsets/whitespaces. So I think is would be convenient that both normal chars and offsets are represented by CharNode so the convertion/merging can be done in-place.

As to styles, I think TextStyle can be made immutable. If we want to change a CharNode's style, we usually push a new TextStyle object into the per-page array of TextStyle, and modify the CharNode's style pointer to point to the new TextStyle. Unused TextStyles are not reclaimed until end of the renderring of the page, but this should not be a big problem.
. > We may convert chars to offsets, but when shall we covert offsets to chars?

Some PDFs use offsets instead of spaces. We may convert an offset between words to a space (or an offset containing a space).

> By modifying styles, usually I meant re-scaling the matrix as well as the font size, or tweaking the positions, and most of time this happens word-wise.

Because chars in a word have same style, we can only create a new TextStyle and update all CharNodes in the TextWord at once.

If the style duplication is really a problem, we can put TextStyle in a set instead of an array.

P.S. is it possible to keep font size constant globally, and only change the matrix? As I suggested in #369 .

> So char->offset means breaking a Word into two, and offset->char means merging two Word's into one.

You mean offsets can not live in Words? How about kerning?

. We can adapt the text output codes in pdf2htmlEX to generate SVG `<text>/<tspan>` instead of `<div>/<span>`, this just requires modest effort. However, the benefit is also small, because a background image is still required (the output becomes SVG text layer + background image).

In order to output high quality HTML or SVG, we need to handle 3 things: texts/fonts, vector graphics, and bitmaps.
- poppler + cairo (CairoOutputDev) is good at handling vector graphics and bitmaps, but handle texts badly (convert texts to graphics in output SVG).
- pdf2htmlEX itself is good at handling texts/fonts, but lacks the ability to handle vector graphics and bitmaps (delegate them to poppler and cairo). This is the main reason why a output page is composed by a text layer and a background image.

So the situation is: In order to output high quality SVG without text/background separation, pdf2htmlEX needs to gain the ability to handle vector graphics and bitmaps, or cairo needs to gain the ability to handle texts/fonts.

Just a thought: maybe it is better to fork `cairo_svg_surface` codes, and merge pdf2htmlEX's text/font handling code into it. As long as the public API of our forked `cairo_svg_surface` keeps unchanged, we don't have to touch `CairoOutputDev`'s code.

However, pure SVG solution also has it drawback: resource consumption of browsers to render the output SVGs is not always bouded -- it can be very high for complicated PDF pages. This is why `--svg-node-count-limit` exists. I think it is still worth to keep a ablility to fallback to (SVG) text layer + bitmap background.

. > So our question is, is there a way to figure out from the font embedded if the text associated with the font is bolded or not.

This can not be done reliably, because in PDF files, texts don't have properties like "bold" or "italic", instead it relies on bold/italic fonts. So best thing you can do is check whether there are strings "bold" or "italic" in a font name (open the dumped font files by fontforge).

There is also no concept "underline" in PDF, it is just a independent line. So there is also no underlined text in pdf2htmlEX-genrated html.

In my opionin, fixed layout epub3 is poor in page transition performance because each page is a xhtml file, and can not be easily viewed in browsers. Instead, I put all pages into one xhtml file and implemented custom page transition and fullscreen in JS, so these features are independent to epub readers and can be viewed directly in browsers.

The converting tool I wrote is JS code running in browser. . Buffering the entire PDF consumes more memory than necessary. What problem are you trying to solve?
. No, pdf2htmlEX loads and processes one page of PDF one time, so the memory reqiurement for processing PDF is constant, not proportional to page numbers.

How do you generate your PDF files? PDF format is not designed for streaming, so you have to wait until a entire PDF is generated to start pdf -> html conversion.

For output streaming, I think you may use [tmpfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tmpfs) to avoid creating physical files and use node.js [`fs.watch()`](https://nodejs.org/api/fs.html#fs_fs_watch_filename_options_listener) to monitor the output file. I think you want the output to be a file rather than a stream, because the network connection may break in the middle and users want to retry in this case.

However, currently pdf2htmlEX is not quite suitable for streaming-while-converting, because the html and css are generated after all pages of PDF are processed, and changing this is non-trivial (but possible).

I have implemented ["covered text handling"](https://github.com/duanyao/pdf2htmlEX/commits/covered_text_handling) initially.
Characters covered by images are detected and (1) are made transparent in text layer, (2) are drawn in background layer.

There are still things to do:
- Fix SplashBackgroundRenderer. The covered text handling requires that text layer is drawn before background, but SplashBackgroundRenderer currently doesn't support this mode, so only svg bg works for now.
- Detect characters covered by paths.
- Handling clip area.
- Speed. The hitting test algorithm is naive, may be slow for complicated pages.
- Merge neighboring transparent chars. Now each char has a `<span>`.
. - The only public interface is `std::vector<bool> & HTMLRenderer::get_chars_covered()`. Optimization could be done in `HTMLRenderer::add_non_char_bbox(double * bbox, int index)` who makes hitting test.
- We have to do char-drawing at least two passes, one for hitting test, one for selective drawing on background. The problem is, how to hint the second pass which chars should be drawn? I don't know a better way than a `chars_covered` array. I'm afraid the data structures used internally in the first pass is irreverent here.
- The Big-O complexity of current algorithm is estimated as O(m*n), m for char count, n for non-char graphics count, if very few chars are covered. Assume each hitting test use 100 CPU cycles, and for a page where m=n=2000, the total time is 0.4G cycles, or 0.2s on a 2GHz core. This is not quite fast, but satisfying me for now, as most of my PDF pages are not that complex.

The dumped jpg files are actually not corrupted, they are in CMYK color space. Unfortunately, it seems most programs can't display them correctly (browsers, GIMP), except 'display' utility in imagemagick. It seems poppler is aware of this issue so it convert these images to png when producing SVG.

Most open source programs use IJG libjpeg to handle jpg. When I test its djpeg utility with the dumped images (`djpeg -bmp -rgb o24.jpg`), it says "Unsupported color conversion request" and fails, so I doubt it support CMYK or not?

So this is arguably a bug in libjpeg or browsers. But If we can't figure out a better solution in short time, I'll workaround this issue by ignoring `--svg-embed-bitmap 0` when non-RGB/gray jpg is encountered. 

By the way, it is better to convert color space of PDF to RGB before feeding to pdf2htmlEX, this not only workaround this issue, but also significantly reduces the output file size (CMYK has 4 channels). You can use acrobat or ghostscript to do this. The command for the latter can be: 
`gs -dNOPAUSE -dBATCH -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -dColorConversionStrategy=/sRGB -sOutputFile=output.pdf input.pdf`
See also https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/wiki/Optimizing-PDF-Files
