@coolwanglu any idea?
. Further reach show that PDF does treat CMYK jpeg inverted in contrast to most other programs.

If create a PDF from a CMYK jpeg file by acrobat, the resulting image dictionary has a `/Decode [1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0]` entry, which effectively invert all color components. pdf2htmlEX can dump jpeg in this PDF without problem.

The pdf in this bug report, in contrast, don't have such inverting `/Decode` entries, and the default ones are `[ 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 ]`, which is an identity transform, so the dumped jpegs have inverted color.

On the other hand, if create a PDF from a RGB jpeg file by acrobat, no `/Decode` entry is presented.

However, I can't find the statement in PDF spec saying that "CMYK jpeg(or all format?) should be intercepted in inverted color". Anyone can help?

So we may check the `/Decode` entry before dumping images: for cmyk jpeg, dump only if inverting `/Decode` exists; for rgb jpeg, dump only if no `/Decode` or identity `/Decode` exists.
. @davidhedley 
 Poppler and cairo create the SVG, and most of the work is done by cairo. Poppler provides a hook to allow client code to decide what to do with images inside a PDF. If client code don't want to handle images (`--svg-embed-bitmap 1`), poppler's default behavior is embedding all images into SVG, and convert format if necessary. It seems poppler decides that CMYK jpeg need to be converted (and color-inverted) to png, so the result is correct.
. @davidhedley 
Thanks! It helped a lot.  See also: [JPEG file embedded in PDF (CMYK)](https://forums.adobe.com/thread/975777).

My conclusion is: PDF readers do color conversion incompatibly with most other programs (including browsers): other programs invert CMYK color if 'Adobe' marker (app14) presents in a jpeg file; while PDF readers don't, they solely rely on /Decode array to invert color. 

In your PDF, the CMYK jpegs' color is not inverted, and have no /Decode array. However they have 'Adobe' marker (you can see them by a hex editor), so if they are dumped, browsers will show them in inverted color.

Why 'Adobe' marker triggers color inverting? This is due to an old photoshop bug (according to doc of libjpeg) -- it wrote CMYK jpeg in inverted color (and wrote 'Adobe' marker), and this became a convention (sigh). However, PostScript and PDF decided not to follow this convention (sigh).

Now this issue is fixed by not dumping CMYK jpeg, see #407.
. This a a known limitation, we use bounding boxes of chars, images, and paths to evaluate chars' visibility. This is simple and fast, but sometimes too conservative.

. How about:

```
struct PDFChar
{
  State * state;
  union
  {
    uint ch; // unicode
    int decomposed_idx;
    float offset;
  }
  enum 
  {
    Character,
    Offset,
    Padding,
    Ligature // ligature that to be decomposed. 
  } type;
}
```

Offset type can add more PDFChar, however when doing covered text handling they can be easily skipped.

P.S. What is the purpose of using a linked list?
. `type == Ligature` means this PDFChar is a decomposed ligature, and `decomposed_idx` is the index of the decomposed ligature in `HTMLTextLine::decomposed_text`.

`type == Offset` means this PDFChar represents a x-offset, and the value is `offset`. This replaces the `HTMLTextLine::offsets`.

. I think this issue is actually a bug of chrome: it doesn't apply CSS `word-spacing` to the space at the beginning of a line.

If both `--optimize-text` and `--space-as-offset` is on, some lines of your converted html file contain leading spaces, and have non-zero `word-spacing` and `white-space:pre` style, so they are not rendered correctly by chrome. So this issue is not related to `--font-size-multiplier`, but `--optimize-text` and `--space-as-offset`.

Simplified test case (also available [at jsfiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/60dvtceh/)):

``` html
<div style="word-spacing:1em; white-space:pre; border:1px red solid;"> Has leading  space, style="word-spacing:1em; white-space:pre"</div>
<div style="white-space:pre; border:1px red solid;"> Has leading  space, style="white-space:pre"</div>
<div style="border:1px red solid;"> Has leading  space, style=""</div>
```

I tested other browsers, webkit also has this bug, IE11 and firefox work as expected.

According to [CSS spec](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-text/#word-spacing-property):

> Word spacing affects each space (U+0020) and non-breaking space (U+00A0), left in the text after the white space processing rules have been applied.

If `white-space:pre` is applied, leading spaces are "left in the text after the white space processing rules  have been applied", so `word-spacing` should be applied to them too. However, chrome/webkit always give leading spaces normal width regardless of `word-spacing`.

So we may want to report the bug to chrome/webkit (I added [one for chrome](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=404444)). Meanwhile, before browsers have fixed this bug, pdf2htmlEX should avoid generating leading spaces.

. This is a chrome/webkit bug.

A simplified test case (also [here](http://jsfiddle.net/q434vyu6/2/)):

``` html
<style>
#span1:after { /* content:''; */ }
</style>
<div>Any thing here.<span id="span1" style="white-space:pre; word-spacing:-1px; display: inline-block;"> Span1 begins with a space. <span id="span2" style="display: inline-block;">Span2</span></span></div>
```

In chrome/webkit, the `#span2` is wrapped to a next line.

This problem requires quite a few conditions to reproduce:
- one span nested in another span.
- the inner span is the last node of the outer span.
- the 2 spans are both `inline-block`.
- the outer span has `white-space:pre`.
- the outer span's text content starts with a space.
- the outer span's `word-spacing` is negative, no matter how small it is.

If any of above conditions is not satisfied, the problem disappears.

Chrome/webkit actually support negative `word-spacing`, I was wrong with this.

I suspect this bug is a combined effect of 2 chrome/webkit bugs:
1. [ inline-block not honored as white-space:pre's last-child of a line](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=35443)
    Sadly, this bug was reported 4 years ago and still not fixed!
2. [word-spacing doesn't correctly applied to leading spaces](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=404444)

pdf2htmlEX already has workarounds for the 2 bug. For the first one, adds a node to the end of divs:

``` css
.t:after {
  content: '';
}
```

For the second one, pdf2htmlEX avoids put spaces at the beginning of divs.

Unfortunately, none of them cover the nested-span situation.

<del>If change `.t:after` in CSS to `.t:after, .t span:after`, this bug can be workarounded. However, I don't know the performance hit of this method. @coolwanglu, what do you think?</del>

. Text selection issue in your file is not related to `--correct-text-visibility`, it also occurs without any params.

The problem is: there is a `div.c` near the end of the first page of the generated html, which covers the whole page, so that makes almost all texts unselectable -- except itself.

A `div.c` coresponds to a clip path in PDF file and uses `overflow:hidden` to achieve  a clipping effect. Unfortunately, it has the side effect of blocking user interactions (including seletion) with elements below a `div.c`.

In fact, `--correct-text-visibility` already handles clipping quite well, and should not have such side effect. So can we suppress `div.c` when `--correct-text-visibility` is on? Can we use CSS clipping when `--correct-text-visibility` is off? Or just get rid of  `div.c` completely?

A shape shall be scan-converted by painting any pixel whose square region intersects the shape, no matter

According to [the comment in pdf2htmlEX code](https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/blob/67dac7d9934c8092a1698347073ca2045d16c747/src/HTMLRenderer/text.cc#L88-L100), this is a known limitation.

`if(is_space && (param.space_as_offset)  && (uLen == 1) && (u[0] == ' '))`. This seems to bring the 'v' back.

. The problem in the first file (http://djvs.co/Untitleddocument.pdf) is caused by zero width space.

The PDF contains zero width space character (U+200B). This char by definition has zero width, but according to the font dictionary and embeded font file, its width is not zero, but 1 (means same as font size). This is not a problem in PDF, because PDF just treats zero width space as a normal char, i.e. respects the char width defined in the font dictionary or the font file.

But it seems that browsers _always_ display U+200B as zero width, no matter what width is defined in the font file. So in the output html file, characters after U+200B are shifted to left in comparison with the PDF.
I don't know whether this behavior is defined by any web standards, it seems that [CSS Fonts spec](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-fonts/) says nothing about this.

One possible solution is, in `HTMLRenderer::drawString()`, append a offset of the width reported by `GfxFont::getNextChar` if we meet U+200B. However, if the font in pdf maps U+200B to a visible glyph, we still loose it after conversion.

. After some thought, I think most (if not all) "illegal html unicode without glyph" should be converted to a `<span class="_ _N"> <span>`, because:
- Browsers implement `letter-spacing` for ZWSP etc differently (should not apply, [FF and IE have bugs](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=253143) ), while implement `letter-spacing` for `inline-block` consistently (not apply at all). So converting an illegal unicode to a ZWSP + offset pair is not ideal.
- In order to largely maintain the sematic, most illegal html unicodes should be converted to delimiters (space or something), not just empty spans. P.S. I think if `--space-as-offset` is on, at least one space should also be retained for each converted offset.

In order to accomplish this, `HTMLTextLine::append_offset(double width)` may be extended to `HTMLTextLine::append_offset(double width, Unicode char)`, means a char (in most cases a space) can be assosiated to the offset. This is called "mixed offset"

`HTMLTextLine::text` field can also be extended to type `vector<HTMLTextUnit>`, and `HTMLTextUnit` is defined as:

```
struct HTMLTextUnit
{
  HTMLTextState * state; // or int state, index of HTMLTextLine::states
  int char_count; // corresponding to how many CharCode
  Unicode unicode;
  float width; // width of offset
}
```

Type of `HTMLTextUnit` is implied:
- Normal text: char_count == 1, unicode > 0, width is NaN (means defined by font/state)
- Pure offset:  char_count == 0, unicode == 0, width != 0
- Mixed offset: char_count > 0, unicode == 0x20 (may be extended), width is not NaN
- Repeating spaces: char_count > 1, unicode == 0x20, width is NaN
- Decomposed ligature
  - First: same as normal text
  - Followings: char_count == 0, unicode > 0
- Not in use: char_count == 0, unicode == 0, width == 0

Some notes:
- `char_count` can be used to sync with `CovertTextDetector`
- Pure/mixed offsets may be merged during text optimazition, and `char_count` and `width` are added up. After merging, removed `HTMLTextUnit` can be marked as "not in use" (don't have to compact the vector).
- <del>Large offsets may converted to "repeating spaces" during text optimazition</del><ins>no, this will invalidate char_count. Large offsets may be converted to muliple normal text units.</ins>.
- `HTMLTextLine::offsets` and `HTMLTextLine::decomposed_text` are not needed anymore.
. `DrawingTracer::update_ctm` traces `OutputDev::updateCTM`, and `OutputDev::updateCTM` provides us with the update to the CTM (which should be muliplied with CTM), not the updated CTM. This behavior seems not stated in poppler's document, but you can see `CairoOutputDev::updateCTM`, it is almost the same as `DrawingTracer::update_ctm`.
. Some thoughts:
I think integrating `DrawingTracer` codes into `TextPageBuilder` is feasible, and putting `bbox` into `CharNode` is good.

However, I'd prefer one flatten array of `CharNode` for all chars in each page, rather than multi-level indirection (TextPage/TextSegment/TextWord/CharNode), because:
- Most post processing algorithms (such as text visibility checking, layout analysis) are bottom-up and only care about individual char's properties, so this indirection is not very useful to them.
- TextSegment/TextWord are built according to certain PDF drawing commands, but in many cases this is sub-optimal so we have `--optimize-text`. I believe an advanced optimization algorithm would unlikely rely on PDF drawing commands, and would rather build a new TextSegment/TextWord tree from bottom up by analyzing the array of `CharNode`.

So we can do this:

```
class CharNode
{
  ...
  TextStyle * style; // or int style_index, or merge TextStyle into CharNode
}
class TextPage
{
  vector<CharNode> chars;
  vector<TextStyle> styles;
  vector<TextSegment> segments;
}

TextWord
{
  ...
  int start; // starting index in TextPage::chars
  int end; // ending index in TextPage::chars
}
```

Another question: what's the advantage of `boost::intrusive::list` over `std:vector` ? Inserting/removing nodes seems rather rare, because during post processings we can (and probably prefer to) just build a new tree and drop the old one. P.S. I don't think "all hidden characters should be removed from the structure", because we want to output transparent texts for them (at least for partially visible chars), so setting a flag on invisible `CharNode` should be enough.
. > For example, if a char is removed (due to hidden by an image, or we decide to covert it to an offset), we need to find the word containing it and modify it accordingly. 

Hidden char should not be removed, just marking it as "transparent" should be OK. Because text style is changed, the TextWord containing the hidden char have to be splitted, this seems complicated.

I'd recommend this workflow to avoid such mess:
1. Build an array of CharNode as well as an array of TextStyle while drawing a page.
   -  (Optional)  Run CovertedTextDetector during the drawing, and mark hidden chars in that array. We may push more TextStyles into the TextStyle array and let hidden chars reference them.
2. Do offset <-> space convertion/merging in the array of CharNode (implement offset as a special CharNode). Push more TextStyles if necessary.
3. Iterate over the array of CharNode, and group chars in a same line (according to x/y coordinate) and with same TextStyle into TextWords, put those TextWords into an array. Push more TextStyles if necessary.
4. Iterate over the array of TextWord, and group them into TextSegments, put those TextSegments into an array. Push more TextStyles if necessary.
5. Travel through the tree, generate HTML/CSS codes.
6. Draw background image, and draw hidden chars according to the array of CharNodes.

So we don't have to modify any TextWord/TextSegment/TextStyle but just build them, so iterator invalidation is not an issue.

This workflow is inspired by [PDFMiner](http://www.unixuser.org/~euske/python/pdfminer/index.html)'s layout analysis algoritm (which I had ported to C++).
. > some characters are transparent as defined in PDF, and some are hidden due to overlapping. Shall we show both of them in HTML (transparently)?

We can add a flag to CharNode to distinguish them. However, it is quite hard to tell whether an char covered by an image is meaningless or not. It is also hard to tell whether an char is completely invisible -- what if the covering image is semi-transparent or clipped? So the safest way is to show all covered/clipped chars as transparent.
. > std::list or intrusive list may be used to solve both problems, I wonder if there are anything we need from vector?

Containers in STL are debugger friendly, I can view them in eclipse CDT or VC++, I'm not sure about boost. I'd also prefer index over iterator, because during debugging I always know the progress of a iteration by check the value of the index.

Vector's other advantages are memory alloaction/dellocation speed and less memory fragment, this may be important or not. If the data structure is not quite dynamic, vector is prefered.
. > if we dump all the chars first, we need to store all the styles for each char, the combine them by comparing the styles again

If we store a pointer or index to TextStyle in each CharNode, we can compare the pointer/index first, which should be fast. At least CharNodes generated by a single drawString() call share a same TextStyle object. If we merge TextStyle into CharNode, we can also add a flag inicating "has same style as last char".
. > And about inserting offset to connect words, actually it can be done by adding a field space_after in the class TextWord

I think this can also be done by adding all possible offsets in step 1. If we find some offsets that are not needed when building TextWord/TextSegment, just ignore them.
. I mean we can pre-allocate all possible offsets in step 1, so that don't have to insert offsets when we decide to merge words afterward.
. When a char is to be appended to the CharNode array, unless we are sure that there is no preceding offset (e.g. "e" in "Hello World"), we always append an CharNode with "offset" type before that char (e.g. "W" in "Hello World"). If the width of the offset is yet to be determined, we can assgin 0 to it so that in following steps we can calculate the actual width.

There are quite a few chances that normal chars and offsets are converted to each other or even merged. E.g. illegal chars may be converted to offsets and further merged with surrounding offsets/whitespaces. So I think is would be convenient that both normal chars and offsets are represented by CharNode so the convertion/merging can be done in-place.

As to styles, I think TextStyle can be made immutable. If we want to change a CharNode's style, we usually push a new TextStyle object into the per-page array of TextStyle, and modify the CharNode's style pointer to point to the new TextStyle. Unused TextStyles are not reclaimed until end of the renderring of the page, but this should not be a big problem.
. > We may convert chars to offsets, but when shall we covert offsets to chars?

Some PDFs use offsets instead of spaces. We may convert an offset between words to a space (or an offset containing a space).

> By modifying styles, usually I meant re-scaling the matrix as well as the font size, or tweaking the positions, and most of time this happens word-wise.

Because chars in a word have same style, we can only create a new TextStyle and update all CharNodes in the TextWord at once.

If the style duplication is really a problem, we can put TextStyle in a set instead of an array.

P.S. is it possible to keep font size constant globally, and only change the matrix? As I suggested in #369 .

> So char->offset means breaking a Word into two, and offset->char means merging two Word's into one.

You mean offsets can not live in Words? How about kerning?

. We can adapt the text output codes in pdf2htmlEX to generate SVG `<text>/<tspan>` instead of `<div>/<span>`, this just requires modest effort. However, the benefit is also small, because a background image is still required (the output becomes SVG text layer + background image).

In order to output high quality HTML or SVG, we need to handle 3 things: texts/fonts, vector graphics, and bitmaps.
- poppler + cairo (CairoOutputDev) is good at handling vector graphics and bitmaps, but handle texts badly (convert texts to graphics in output SVG).
- pdf2htmlEX itself is good at handling texts/fonts, but lacks the ability to handle vector graphics and bitmaps (delegate them to poppler and cairo). This is the main reason why a output page is composed by a text layer and a background image.

So the situation is: In order to output high quality SVG without text/background separation, pdf2htmlEX needs to gain the ability to handle vector graphics and bitmaps, or cairo needs to gain the ability to handle texts/fonts.

Just a thought: maybe it is better to fork `cairo_svg_surface` codes, and merge pdf2htmlEX's text/font handling code into it. As long as the public API of our forked `cairo_svg_surface` keeps unchanged, we don't have to touch `CairoOutputDev`'s code.

However, pure SVG solution also has it drawback: resource consumption of browsers to render the output SVGs is not always bouded -- it can be very high for complicated PDF pages. This is why `--svg-node-count-limit` exists. I think it is still worth to keep a ablility to fallback to (SVG) text layer + bitmap background.

. That means we want to handle bitmaps ourselves (not by SplashOutputDev/CairoOutputDev)? If so, I'd suggest output SVG insead of HTML, it is actually simpler: `font-size-multiplier` will be unnecessary, and paths, clips, text strokes and masked images can be mapped directly to SVG counterparts. Thus, both SplashOutputDev/CairoOutputDev are not needed in most cases.

If the output SVG is too complex, we would still need SplashOutputDev, and delegate vector graphics to it. In this case, we need to correct the visibility of texts and bitmaps remained in the SVG layer like what we currently do.

So maybe we don't need CairoOutputDev anymore :).

. > So our question is, is there a way to figure out from the font embedded if the text associated with the font is bolded or not.

This can not be done reliably, because in PDF files, texts don't have properties like "bold" or "italic", instead it relies on bold/italic fonts. So best thing you can do is check whether there are strings "bold" or "italic" in a font name (open the dumped font files by fontforge).

There is also no concept "underline" in PDF, it is just a independent line. So there is also no underlined text in pdf2htmlEX-genrated html.

PDFs usually don't have any information about tables (tables are just represented as texts and lines) ( [read this article for more info](https://blog.idrsolutions.com/2009/04/pdf-text/)), so there is nothing pdf2htmlEX can do. If you want to recognize tables in PDFs, you'll need some [layout analysis](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_layout_analysis) tools.

. Converting output of pdf2htmlex to epub3 is definitely doable (we did that actually). Of cause you have to do some programing to generate the navigation document and the OPF.

What epub readers are you targeting? I believe most epub3 readers are based on morden browser engines, and SVG produced by pdf2htmlex (via cario) should be viewable in browsers. Morden browsers support a mixture of SVG 1.1 and SVG 1.2 tiny, by the way.

. It seems the latest [EPUB3 spec](http://www.idpf.org/epub/301/spec/epub-contentdocs.html#sec-css-2.1) still forbids `unicode-bidi`. However if major epub3 readers accept `unicode-bidi`, I think it is not a big problem to violate the spec. If you must have the generated EPUB to pass a validator, you may dynamicly insert the `unicode-bidi` rule via JS.
. @anteprandium I did convert output of pdf2htmlex to epub3, however it is not [fixed layout epub3](http://www.idpf.org/epub/31/spec/epub-contentdocs.html#sec-fixed-layouts). In my opionin, fixed layout epub3 is poor in page transition performance because each page is a xhtml file, and can not be easily viewed in browsers. Instead, I put all pages into one xhtml file and implemented custom page transition and fullscreen in JS, so these features are independent to epub readers and can be viewed directly in browsers.

The converting tool I wrote is JS code running in browser. It parses the output xhtml of pdf2htmlex, and generates OPF, navigation and content files, and packages them into epub using [zip.js](https://github.com/gildas-lormeau/zip.js). The output files of pdf2htmlex is also packaged as zip before converting. This tool is part of a commercial software and is not publicly available yet, sorry. If you don't have special requirements, maybe using [sigil](https://sigil-ebook.com/) to import the output of pdf2htmlEX is easier, as mentioned by the original post.

The params of pdf2htmlEX I used looks like (hope helpful):

```
#!/bin/sh
pdf2htmlEX --fit-width 800 --hdpi 200 --vdpi 200 --font-size-multiplier 10 --heps 0.5 --veps 0.5 --css-filename content.css --embed cfijO --bg-format svg --svg-node-count-limit 1000 --svg-embed-bitmap 0 --correct-text-visibility 1 --dest-dir $1.sout $1 content.xhtml
```
. A PDF file can't be read sequentially, and the output of pdf2htmlEX is not always a single file.
. Buffering the entire PDF consumes more memory than necessary. What problem are you trying to solve?
. No, pdf2htmlEX loads and processes one page of PDF one time, so the memory reqiurement for processing PDF is constant, not proportional to page numbers.

How do you generate your PDF files? PDF format is not designed for streaming, so you have to wait until a entire PDF is generated to start pdf -> html conversion.

For output streaming, I think you may use [tmpfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tmpfs) to avoid creating physical files and use node.js [`fs.watch()`](https://nodejs.org/api/fs.html#fs_fs_watch_filename_options_listener) to monitor the output file. I think you want the output to be a file rather than a stream, because the network connection may break in the middle and users want to retry in this case.

However, currently pdf2htmlEX is not quite suitable for streaming-while-converting, because the html and css are generated after all pages of PDF are processed, and changing this is non-trivial (but possible).
. Yeah, I am aware of the limitation of `--svg-node-count-limit` and `--force-png-background` can be a rescue. But I can't promise to implement this feature any time soon. Patch is welcome!

. That's because we must handle closed sub path in which case we loop back to the first point.
The actual index `j` should never reach `n`:

https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/blob/master/src/DrawingTracer.cc#L246

``` C++
            if (p == n)
            {
                if (subpath->isClosed())
                    j = 0; // if sub path is closed, go back to starting point
                else
                    break;
            }
            else
                  j = p;
```

I believe we did! This is how we installed pdf2htmlEX on a clean install of Fedora 17:

yum install \
autoconf \
automake \
bzip2 \
cairo-devel \
cmake \
fontconfig-devel \
gcc \
gcc-c++ \
giflib-devel \
git \
gnu-getopt \
libjpeg-devel \
libpng-devel \
libspiro-devel \
libtiff-devel \
libtool \
libtool-ltdl-devel \
openjpeg-devel \
pango-devel \
tar \
unzip

wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-0.22.1.tar.gz
tar xzf poppler-0.22.1.tar.gz
cd xzf poppler-0.22.1
./configure --enable-xpdf-headers
make
make install

wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-data-0.4.6.tar.gz
tar xzf poppler-data-0.4.6.tar.gz
cd poppler-data-0.4.6
make install

wget https://github.com/fontforge/fontforge/archive/master.zip
unzip master.zip
cd fontforge-master
./autogen.sh
./configure
make
make install

git clone --depth 1 git://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX.git
cd pdf2htmlEX
PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig cmake .
make
make install

. I updated the implementation for sanitizing the split page filenames to not rely on regex, based loosely on the gnuplot implementation.

Regarding page naming behavior, I've implemented the following:
- If `output-filename` is not specified, use `<input-filename-without-suffix>%d.page`
- If `output-filename` is specified, but it has no `%d`, use `<output-filename-without-suffix>%d.<output-filename-suffix>`
- If `output-filename` contains the placeholder, use that.

rajasuba:
What is mean by fallback mode? Why do we use it? Could you please explain it...
. As far as I know, there is no option to get comment in converted HTML content !. I am facing the above issue in chrome and safari. Whereas in FireFox it is working fine. Any idea to sort this out?
. Hi,

The above issue occurs only in - webkit web browsers like chrome and safari - which provides support for ligatures - whereas browser like firefox does not.

> A ligature is a combination of two or more letters joined as a single glyph
>     (For more info : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typographic_ligature)

**​Reason for the issue***

This issue with missing characters is due to `ligature support` provided by these modern browsers - let me explain how

1.Our tool while converting - it converts characters to glyphs using poppler for rendering - now these browser when they come across characters like `tt` `tf` `ti` `ff` `fi` consider them to be ligature and searches for glyphs corresponding to `tt` and not `t` `t`

2.Since they do not have their corresponding glyphs - they just skip the characters and renders the rest - so, we fount the characters missing

**This could be solved by** 
1. Disabling/ Turning-off the ligature in these browsers - embedding the css in the generating content

Refer:

> https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/issues/543
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19591746/prevent-ligatures-in-safari-mavericks-ios7-via-css
> https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings
> http://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature

Please correct me if I am wrong.
. Also please refer : https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/issues/675
. Hi Leon,

Please try with the following if you hadn't already.
https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/wiki/Optimizing-PDF-Files

Compressing pdf files increase our efficiency in the following ways,
1. Reduces the size of input pdf - due to which the conversion speed from pdf to html gets increased
2. The size of the html file produced from the compressed file is lesser in size due to which the rendering of the page would be faster.
- Lesser the weight of the html page - faster the rendering speed by the browser.

. Hi,

The above issue occurs only in - webkit web browsers like chrome and safari - which provides support for ligatures - whereas browser like firefox does not.

> A ligature is a combination of two or more letters joined as a single glyph
>     (For more info : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typographic_ligature)

**​Reason for the issue***

This issue with missing characters is due to `ligature support` provided by these modern browsers - let me explain how

1.Our tool while converting - it converts characters to glyphs using poppler for rendering - now these browser when they come across characters like `tt` `tf` `ti` `ff` `fi` consider them to be ligature and searches for glyphs corresponding to `tt` and not `t` `t`

2.Since they do not have their corresponding glyphs - they just skip the characters and renders the rest - so, we fount the characters missing

**This could be solved by** 
1. Disabling/ Turning-off the ligature in these browsers - embedding the css in the generating content

Refer:

> https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/issues/543
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19591746/prevent-ligatures-in-safari-mavericks-ios7-via-css
> https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings
> http://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature

Please correct me if I am wrong.
. Also please refer : https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/issues/675

```
< Depends: ${shlibs:Depends}, ${misc:Depends}, libpoppler27 (>= 0.20.3) | libpoppler28 | libpoppler43, libpng12-0, libjpeg8, libfontforge1
> Depends: ${shlibs:Depends}, ${misc:Depends}, libpng12-0, libjpeg8, libfontforge1
```

And it the library is automatically imported in the dependencies in the binary package with the version it has be build with (required anyway): 

```
Depends: libc6 (>= 2.4), libfontforge1, libgcc1 (>= 1:4.4.0), libpoppler44 (>= 0.24.5), libpython2.7 (>= 2.7), libstdc++6 (>= 4.8), libpng12-0, libjpeg8
```

So I would suggest to let dpkg deal with it automatically: as you enforce the version in the build dependencies (libpoppler-dev (>= 0.20.3)), it should to be safe anyway.

As we are at it, when building, dpkg complains about the (useless?) dependency on python-dev:

```
dpkg-shlibdeps: warning: package could avoid a useless dependency if debian/pdf2htmlex/usr/bin/pdf2htmlEX was not linked against libpython2.7.so.1.0 (it uses none of the library's symbols)
```

Maybe you could just remove it.

Thank you very much bot the great job.
. In my case, it is required, as it is build on a system with libpoppler44 installed. Trying to install the package anywhere else will fail at runtime. 

If you look at the package in the PPA[1], it is the same (the version of libpoppler installed in the building system is in the deps): 

```
Depends: libc6 (>= 2.14), libfontforge1, libgcc1 (>= 1:4.1.1), libpoppler43 (>= 0.24.1), libstdc++6 (>= 4.8), libpng12-0, libjpeg8
```

[1] https://launchpad.net/~coolwanglu/+archive/pdf2htmlex/+sourcepub/3660881/+listing-archive-extra

All the dependencies listed here except libpng12-0 and libjpeg8 come from ${shlibs:Depends} (I just tried a build). You can find more information on the way the shared libs are managed here: https://www.debian.org/doc/debian-policy/ch-sharedlibs.html (the variable is also explained)

In our case ${misc:Depends} seems not to be used, but it is still a good practice to have it: 

```
       All commands of this type, besides documenting what dependencies may be
       needed on their man pages, will automatically generate a substvar
       called ${misc:Depends}. If you put that token into your debian/control
       file, it will be expanded to the dependencies debhelper figures you
       need.
```

Forget what I said for libpython, it seems to come from the build system on Raspberry Pi. 
. I will try it out tomorrow and tell you.

. I've got horizontal navigation working with swiper (https://github.com/nolimits4web/Swiper) and intend to ultimately support a landscape two page view. 
Pdf2htmlEx's vertical dynamic page loading works better in my tests than horizontal with swiper and slight modifications to pdf2htmlex. I intend to find a good solution for this and would prefer to not introduce additional dependencies.

. You rock!
. https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/905526/6_pdfsam_SU_2013_09.pdf
. I believe I found it. I also noticed that PNGs were corrupt (technically) as they didn't have the IEND written to them.
Looking through the code I noticed that writer->close() was not being called in SplashBackgroundRenderer.cc

So I added  the call after the call to writer->writePointers and both JPG and PNG seem OK now

```
if(!writer->close()){
    throw "Cannot close out image";
}
```
. Thanks!

Mick Giles
mick@mickgiles.com

yu-liang-kono:
I try to reduce woff file size by merging woff files with the same font name in a post-processing way. Say, I find out f19f.woff and f1a6.woff are both `IIKSQH+MS-Gothic`, then merged them into a woff file like `IIKSQH+MS-Gothic.woff` by fontforge. And replace @font-face src with correct woff file in css file.

Not sure whether or not it is a correct approach, but the total woff file size is reduced significantly after merging duplicate fonts. And I don't encounter anything weird by using the merged font.

The repository is here. https://github.com/yu-liang-kono/pdf2htmlEXOptimize
Please use it at your own risk and any suggestion is welcomed.

Say, I find out f19f.woff and f1a6.woff are both `IIKSQH+MS-Gothic`, then merged them into a woff file like `IIKSQH+MS-Gothic.woff` by fontforge. And replace @font-face src with correct woff file in css file.

Not sure whether or not it is a correct approach, but the total woff file size is reduced significantly after merging duplicate fonts. And I don't encounter anything weird by using the merged font.

The repository is here. https://github.com/yu-liang-kono/pdf2htmlEXOptimize
Please use it at your own risk and any suggestion is welcomed.

DevanR:
Hi there. I faced the same error. Just wanted to share my steps and eventual fix. It was the third step that resolved the issue for me.
1. Update local gcc to to a version that supports c++0x (I used gcc-4.9)
2. Make sure that the latest version is being used, with "gcc --version", "hash gcc" and so on.
3. Cmake uses "cc" and "c++" commands. I had to symlink those commands found in /usr/bin to the latest gcc and g++ respectively.

Hope this helps others to use and contribute to this cool project.
. Hi there. I faced the same error. Just wanted to share my steps and eventual fix. It was the third step that resolved the issue for me.
1. Update local gcc to to a version that supports c++0x (I used gcc-4.9)
2. Make sure that the latest version is being used, with "gcc --version", "hash gcc" and so on.
3. Cmake uses "cc" and "c++" commands. I had to symlink those commands found in /usr/bin to the latest gcc and g++ respectively.

Hope this helps others to use and contribute to this cool project.
.

Someone said that cmake cache made this problem sometimes. It's work for me.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26091174/cmake-complaints-about-lack-of-support-of-c0x-of-the-compiler-despite-the-late
. @duanyao  You are right. I installed the poppler right but did not refresh the cache of dynamic linker of system. It works after adding `RUN ldconfig -v` in my dockerfile.
Thanks a lot!
. Here is my docker file finnally.

#Dockerfile to build a pdf2htmlEx image oracle jdk8 tomcat7 
#FROM jdk_you_build_before 
#
ENV PDF2HTMLEX_HOME /pdf_temp
RUN mkdir -p "$PDF2HTMLEX_HOME"
WORKDIR $PDF2HTMLEX_HOME
#Install git and all dependencies
RUN yum group install -y "Development Tools"
RUN yum install -y  cmake gcc gnu-getopt libpng-devel cairo-devel  libspiro-devel freetype-devel   libjpeg-turbo-devel python-devel pango-devel libxml2-devel libtool-ltdl-devel git
#install poppler poppler-data
RUN curl -fSLO http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-0.37.0.tar.xz && tar -xvf poppler-0.37.0.tar.xz
RUN cd poppler-0.37.0 &&./configure  --enable-xpdf-headers --prefix=/usr&& make && make install
RUN curl -fSLO http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz && tar -xvf poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz
RUN cd poppler-data-0.4.7 && make prefix=/usr install

#install fontforge
RUN git clone https://github.com/coolwanglu/fontforge.git fontforge.git
RUN cd fontforge.git && git checkout pdf2htmlEX && ./autogen.sh && ./configure  --enable-xpdf-headers --prefix=/usr && make && make install

#config pkg-config path
ENV PKG_CONFIG_PATH=$PKG_CONFIG_PATH:/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig/:/usr/lib/pkgconfig/

#Clone and install the pdf2htmlEX git repo
RUN git clone git://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX.git
RUN cd pdf2htmlEX && cmake . && make && make install

#refresh lib reference
RUN ldconfig -v

#clean the image
RUN rm poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz && rm poppler-0.37.0.tar.xz && yum clean all
RUN mkdir -p /pdf
VOLUME /pdf
WORKDIR /pdf
CMD ["pdf2htmlEX"]
. Run 'dpkg --get-selections | grep poppler | awk '{ print $1}'| xargs sudo apt-get -y --purge autoremove' first,  and install a poppler with correct version. 
Finally I installed it sucessfully.

ChrisCinelli:
I could not find the command line option. I did not know of `man pdf2htmlEX`. I added a copy here so it can be indexed by Google: https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/wiki/Command-line
. Created pull request in #153 
. Just to give you some context:
- I have a page that is supposed to embedded PDF documents.
- The converted document is on Amazon S3 and a different domain. 
- I need to select text in the PDF and be able to capture the selection. I am using `doc.getSelection().toString()`.
- I am putting the converted pdf in an iframe but if I use the src attribute in the iframe, I am not able to access the iframe content because cross-domain policy. So I read the HTML with an AJAX and my code look like:
  
  ```
                  $page.html('<iframe id="document-frame" style="width:940px; height:500px;" frameborder="0"></iframe>');
                  var doc, iframe = $("#document-frame", that.$page)[0];
  
                  var iframe_window = iframe.contentWindow;    
                  doc = iframe_window.document;
                  doc.write(data.html);  
  ```

Unfortunately doing this makes the converted PDF pages are blank. Most likely because init_after_loading_content is not called. In fact if I later do:

```
                            var viewer = new iframe_window.pdf2htmlEX.Viewer({
                                 container_id : 'page-container', 
                                 sidebar_id : 'sidebar',
                                 outline_id : 'nope', //We do not want sidebars!
                                 page_urls : [
                             ]
                            });                                     
                            viewer.init_after_loading_content();
```

Everything works correctly but I have to recreate an extra Viewer object. With this patch in the pull request  I could avoid to create a new object and directly call `iframe_window.pdf2htmlEXViewerInstance.init_after_loading_content()`

Regarding your points:
- Putting an instance of a object inside the "class"  that create it sound a little weird in Javascript. And having to access and object inside another object look even more hackish.  This is not the common way to use the singleton pattern in Javascript. Personally I would have used the [module pattern](http://www.adequatelygood.com/JavaScript-Module-Pattern-In-Depth.html) for the whole thing but I do not want to modify too much your Javascript. Assigning the `pdf2htmlEX.Viewer` object that you create to a global variable, sounds a pretty good option.
- pdf2htmlEXViewerInstance does not look like the perfect name for me, too. But as you said I do not have a better one. Some alternatives: pdf2htmlEX_viewer_instance, viewerInstance, p2hInstance, instance, viewer ...
. Good for me! After you merge, when you have some time, please update the Ubuntu repo! Thank you!

Got a way to reduce the 3rd party dependence, use g_mkdtemp from glib-2(this library used by poppler too), will update the modified source code soon.
. sorry, I am newbie of github and c/c++, and I finally wrote a mkdtemp function in a smipler way,

``` c
#ifdef _WIN32
#include <direct.h>
char* mkdtemp(char* name_template) {
  auto p = mktemp(name_template);
  if(p  == nullptr){
    return nullptr;
  }

  int err = _mkdir(name_template);
  if (err < 0 ) {
    return nullptr;
  }
  return name_template;
}
#endif
```

dsherret:
I was thinking that the parameter shouldn't be allowed unless the other parameters will produce a single HTML file.

The main benefits of this approach would be convenience and speed as an extra write, read, and delete from the disk would be unnecessary when outputting to stdout (delete only necessary if the file is temporary). 

It could also be a benefit if the user does not have write permissions but has read permissions to the disk (maybe even accepting a file piped in). However, since intermediate files are produced then this solution to this case would be useless.

I'd help out, but I haven't programmed in c++ in a few years. I'm not sure how worth it it is to implement this feature now that I think about it more.
. Yes, you're right. This seems to only be a nice feature for convenience. I'm going to close this issue for now until I find some time to implement it in the future.

X4:
Good idea, but this only makes only sense for packing small images. Therefore you need a 2nd compilation phase, which packs all images with a dimension less than 10% of the source canvas into one mega-sprite.

It means that only on PDFs with many small images you will have a noticeable impact on file-size and load-time.
. @coolwanglu understandable and thanks for the quick reply :) 
`--image-postprocessor` would be the possible solution, it sounds great and would fix this issue altogether.

Chrismarsh:
Following here http://people.freedesktop.org/~dbn/pkg-config-guide.html, setting 

```
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig
```

and then 

```
rm -rf CMakeFiles
rm CMakeCache.txt
rm MakeFile
```

then

```
cmake .
```

fixed this error for me.
. @coolwanglu Yea, that'd be great

A new and extensive search method in `pdf2htmlEX.js` would really be great. One of the nice features of PDF are its search abilities and bookmarks, so a new extensive API for that in your library would really contribute to making PDFs accesible as html.

IE8之所以还有很多人用，根本原因是因为还有大量的XP用户的浏览器最高只能升级到IE8，又不会去换chrome等浏览器。做互联网应用的，起码在中国国内，可以忽略IE6、7，也不敢贸然舍弃IE8。

主题: Re: [pdf2htmlEX] IE8兼容问题 (#222)

不兼容是说有可能会用到一些特殊功能，具体取决于转换的PDF和使用的参数。其中一个问题应该是css transformation。

现在pdf2htmlEX的效果是非常依赖一部分css功能，而ie8主要对他们支持不够好，我一直没有找到好的解决办法。“市场占有率”的话，一方面考虑到阅读在线文档的用户，ie8使用率不见得有多少（当然我没有数据）；另外随着ie11发布，我想ie8也很快就会被淘汰了。很多网站和库（比如jquery2)已经不考虑ie9以前的版本了）

—

marcsanfacon:
I did some investigating on this and used pdftohtml & pdftotext from poppler and it gives the same results - accents showing in UTF-8.

Following text (last character is a smiley in the PDF):
Présentation
• Ceci est une présentation de Marc Sanfaçon
• J’aime bien les caractères 

gives:
PrÃ©sentation
â€¢ Ceci est une prÃ©sentation de Marc SanfaÃ§on
â€¢ Jâ€™aime bien les caractÃ¨res ïŠ

When converted from UTF-8, we get:
 Présentation
�?� Ceci est une présentation de Marc Sanfaçon
�?� J�??aime bien les caractères ��?
. I get the same result as without it - seeing UTF-8 characters.

Do you think the problem would be poppler here or pdf2htmlEX?
. I found more information. What seem to be missing is the charset in the html page

I added the following line to the generated HTML & it worked perfectly.
   <META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">

Looks like the generated file from the compiled version of rubypdf put the charset in the generated file, but the one I compiled does not.

Also, poppler's pdftohtml works, as it put the charset in the file. It does not render properly in Chrome because it uses iFrame, but works in Firefox.

I did not find an option to force output of the charset. Is there?

Thanks.
. I found the problem. It is the '\r' in the manifest files. I modified the code to filter the whitespaces before comparing the lines with """ and everything works A1!

I will do a pull request with this fix, the MinGW port as well as 2 other things I added.

Thanks!
. I will remove it.

progression?

MarcGodard:
Wow, Thanks for the quick reply. That works.
. Found the solutions. Here for anyone else.

document.getElementById('iFrameInsert').contentWindow.pdf2htmlEX.defaultViewer.fit_height();
. http://www.mediafire.com/view/28n9tn9v5mtlau7/testPDF%282%29.pdf
. http://www.mediafire.com/view/28n9tn9v5mtlau7/testPDF%282%29.pdf

I tried making the pages not hide, but still had this issue.
. I saw it with all files. I was using Chrome, not Chromium.
. What -webkit-transform: translateZ(0); does is initiate the iPad and Mac to use the GPU to calculate the page. When it is CPU only, large complicated pdfs (in HTML) scroll really slow.
. Another thing to improve scrolling even more is to add \* { -webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch; } to the pdf.html's css.

This makes it scroll on ipad like it does everywhere else.
. Doh I should have seen that.

. Actually it wouldn't, 1) I already use PDF2HTMLEx for the HTML, and 2) What I do is make the user click on the HTML and a popup bring up that section (cutout) in an image and zoomed in. The problem is calculating what part of that image to bring up because it doesn't match the HTML version. brettz9:
Here's a sample of HTML which is recognized by jsPDF for conversion into PDF: ``` html

About jsPDF

Simply include the jsPDF library in your <head>, generate your PDF using the many built-in functions, then hook up a button to trigger the download. All the examples here use jQuery.

``` I was making the assumption that the parser of that project was only aware of this form of HTML structure as opposed to recognizing the resultant CSS styles, but perhaps I am wrong. If it doesn't already, it would be nice if that project could parse and handle any form of CSS, but I guess I was premature in introducing this on your issue list instead of that project's. :) . Here's a sample of HTML which is recognized by jsPDF for conversion into PDF: ``` html

About jsPDF

Simply include the jsPDF library in your <head>, generate your PDF using the many built-in functions, then hook up a button to trigger the download. All the examples here use jQuery.

``` I was making the assumption that the parser of that project was only aware of this form of HTML structure as opposed to recognizing the resultant CSS styles, but perhaps I am wrong. If it doesn't already, it would be nice if that project could parse and handle any form of CSS, but I guess I was premature in introducing this on your issue list instead of that project's. :) .

Hi coolwanglu,

I'm having issues properly installing pdf2htmlEX. I've done a bit of research on some git threads that report similar issues; particularly regarding poppler and fontforge dependencies.

When I use homebrew to install pdf2html, it goes fine for a moment, and then I get an error output of:

==> ./configure --prefix=/usr/local/Cellar/fontforge/20120731 --enable-double --
checking for suffix of executables... 
checking whether we are cross compiling... configure: error: in `/private/tmp/fontforge-vHSU/fontforge-20120731-b':
configure: error: cannot run C compiled programs.
If you meant to cross compile, use`--host'.
See `config.log' for more details.

But I can run C compiled programs just fine, so I don't understand the context here.

And -  when I use cmake to install pdf2htmlEX,  it complains that it can't find fontforge.h.  But font forge has indeed been installed.

As for poppler, I'm not sure what my poppler version is, because though homebrew seems to have installed the most recent version okay. However, "man poppler" or "poppler --version" are not recognized at all. Poppler's documentation is thin, and I know of no way to run a sample poppler process just as a test to see if it's working. 

I've seen pdf2htmlEX working _great_ on other OSX machines (I'm using Mavericks, btw) . Any tips would be greatly appreciated !  There must be some diagnostics I can run that flush the problem out into the open, I just don't know what they are at this point.

Thanks !

. Thanks to @duanyao and thanks to a friend I think I have solved my issues. . Here are the steps I used. Tested on a fresh and updated Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS x86_64. Install build tools. ~$ sudo apt-get install build-essential Install and check dependencies. ~$ sudo apt-get install cmake pkg-config ~$ getopt -V getopt from util-linux 2.20.1 Install dependencies to compile poppler. ~$ sudo apt-get install libpng12-0 libpng12-dev libjpeg62 libjpeg62-dev fontconfig libfontconfig1-dev Install poppler-data from sources. ~$ wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz ~$ tar zxvf poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz ~$ cd poppler-data-0.4.7 ~$ make ~$ sudo make install Install poppler from sources. ~$ wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-0.26.4.tar.xz ~$ tar xJvf poppler-0.26.4.tar.xz ~$ cd poppler-0.26.4 ~$ ./configure --enable-xpdf-headers ~$ make ~$ sudo make install Install fontforge from sources (coolwanglu fork). ~$ sudo apt-get install packaging-dev pkg-config python-dev libpango1.0-dev libglib2.0-dev ~$ libxml2-dev giflib-dbg libjpeg-dev libtiff-dev uthash-dev ~$ wget https://github.com/coolwanglu/fontforge/archive/pdf2htmlEX.zip ~$ unzip pdf2htmlEX.zip ~$ cd fontforge-pdf2htmlEX ~$ ./autogen.sh ~$ ./configure ~$ make ~$ sudo make install ~$ sudo ldconfig Install pdf2htmlEX from sources. ~$ git clone git://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX.git ~$ cd pdf2htmlEX ~$ cmake . && make && sudo make install . @duanyao - Is that title better for you? . @duanyao, please let me know if you think you can make the suggested changes for me to try out. Thanks . Not sure I understand what you mean by div.c ? My understanding is that it's not always the same div causing the glass effect. . Thanks. Optimally, we are looking for a programmatic solution here as I don't have the option to do this manually, however, a programmatic solution to give options to the users may be workable. So, do you believe that if this class 'c' is removed that it will resolve this issue of non-selectable text? Is it only this class 'c' that would be causing these types of issues? I've tried manually removing the class 'c' in articles where this issue exists and It seems to mess up the formatting when it's removed unless you update the right div tag to remove that class and even then there is still formatting loss in some cases. I'm just thinking that we could offer to user to remove one class 'c' at a time and have them visually inspect result and if no help or messes up formatting then we would give the user option to try another class 'c' removal. . My observation is that when doing this it actually causes text to be removed versus just removing "c" from the class list. Most of the manual tests I've tried with a variety of documents seem to allow text to be selected after just removing the "c" class from the div. . Thanks to @duanyao and thanks to a friend I think I have solved my issues. . Here are the steps I used. Tested on a fresh and updated Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS x86_64. Install build tools. ~$ sudo apt-get install build-essential Install and check dependencies. ~$ sudo apt-get install cmake pkg-config ~$ getopt -V getopt from util-linux 2.20.1 Install dependencies to compile poppler. ~$ sudo apt-get install libpng12-0 libpng12-dev libjpeg62 libjpeg62-dev fontconfig libfontconfig1-dev Install poppler-data from sources. ~$ wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz ~$ tar zxvf poppler-data-0.4.7.tar.gz ~$ cd poppler-data-0.4.7 ~$ make ~$ sudo make install Install poppler from sources. ~$ wget http://poppler.freedesktop.org/poppler-0.26.4.tar.xz ~$ tar xJvf poppler-0.26.4.tar.xz ~$ cd poppler-0.26.4 ~$ ./configure --enable-xpdf-headers ~$ make ~$ sudo make install Install fontforge from sources (coolwanglu fork). ~$ sudo apt-get install packaging-dev pkg-config python-dev libpango1.0-dev libglib2.0-dev ~$ libxml2-dev giflib-dbg libjpeg-dev libtiff-dev uthash-dev ~$ wget https://github.com/coolwanglu/fontforge/archive/pdf2htmlEX.zip ~$ unzip pdf2htmlEX.zip ~$ cd fontforge-pdf2htmlEX ~$ ./autogen.sh ~$ ./configure ~$ make ~$ sudo make install ~$ sudo ldconfig Install pdf2htmlEX from sources. ~$ git clone git://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX.git ~$ cd pdf2htmlEX ~$ cmake . && make && sudo make install . @duanyao - Is that title better for you? . @duanyao, please let me know if you think you can make the suggested changes for me to try out. Thanks . Not sure I understand what you mean by div.c ? My understanding is that it's not always the same div causing the glass effect. . Thanks. Optimally, we are looking for a programmatic solution here as I don't have the option to do this manually, however, a programmatic solution to give options to the users may be workable. So, do you believe that if this class 'c' is removed that it will resolve this issue of non-selectable text? Is it only this class 'c' that would be causing these types of issues? I've tried manually removing the class 'c' in articles where this issue exists and It seems to mess up the formatting when it's removed unless you update the right div tag to remove that class and even then there is still formatting loss in some cases. I'm just thinking that we could offer to user to remove one class 'c' at a time and have them visually inspect result and if no help or messes up formatting then we would give the user option to try another class 'c' removal. . My observation is that when doing this it actually causes text to be removed versus just removing "c" from the class list. Most of the manual tests I've tried with a variety of documents seem to allow text to be selected after just removing the "c" class from the div. egrubbs:
You can try https://launchpad.net/~edwin-grubbs/+archive/ubuntu/ppa for trusty. It also updates poppler, pdf.js and fontforge.
. Try

```
  pfd2htmlEX --correct-text-visibility 1
```

It worked for me. I'm not sure why it is turned off by default.
. The best tool out there is wkhtmltopdf.
There is some issue with the text/fonts produced by pdf2htmlex that causes problems with wkhtmltopdf, so I have to use this option:

```
pdf2htmlEX --proof 1
```

To make wkhtmltopdf use the right css, it needs to be run with this option:

```
wkhtmltopdf --print-media-type
```

Silarn:
I did some tests using variants of the QupZilla browser, based on Qt, and the problem seems to be deeper. Frankly I'm not sure if it can be solved, and it also seems that the Qt library is at fault as using the back ported QtWebKit 2.3 on Qt 4.7+ still gives the same font issues. Whereas Qt5 works almost identically to Chrome (with the same faults).

This may not be something fixable on this end. However, I did discover a separate issue with using external fonts on some occasions. For instance, "Arial Narrow, Bold" becomes embedded as "ArialNarrow Bold" - which is the name exported by pdf2htmlEX. However, this is not the name browsers expect - which should be 'Arial Narrow' + font weight: bold. I've worked around this by using fc-match against the first part of the name (ArialNarrow without the Bold), which supplies the 'proper' font family name. When I fix this in the DOM, all works as expected - since said fonts already use font-weight: bold / font-style: italic when using external fonts.
. I did some tests using variants of the QupZilla browser, based on Qt, and the problem seems to be deeper. If create a PDF from a CMYK jpeg file by acrobat, the resulting image dictionary has a /Decode [1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 1.0 0.0] entry, which effectively invert all color components. pdf2htmlEX can dump jpeg in this PDF without problem. On the other hand, if create a PDF from a RGB jpeg file by acrobat, no /Decode entry is presented. When I try the "cleaned" PDF, I get: ``` pdf2htmlEX --process-type3 1 Page-1fromTCX-B757-AFM-28A_nowatermark.processed.pdf Preprocessing: 1/1 zsh: segmentation fault (core dumped) pdf2htmlEX --process-type3 1 Page-1fromTCX-B757-AFM-28A_nowatermark.processed.pdf ``` On different Linux system, instead of a core dump, pdf2htmlEX hangs forever. . These are all cases where the page has a rotation which is not being catered for in CairoBackgroundRenderer. The solution is as simple as adding: ``` int pageRotate = doc->getPageRotate(pageno); if (pageRotate == 90 || pageRotate == 270) { double tmp = page_height; page_height = page_width; page_width = tmp; } ``` to `CairoBackgroundRenderer::render_page(PDFDoc * doc, int pageno)` This fixes all the test cases in the example ZIP file I provided Could you include this fix in the next release? . I have also seen the issue of word-spacing not being correctly handled in Chrome/Webkit with leading spaces. My current solution is to insert a U+200B (Zero width non-break space) character at the start of any text node with a leading space. Chrome will then handle the word-spacing setting correctly (it has no impact on Firefox rendering). Given how differently different browsers interprest word-spacing, can we just avoid using it for adjusting the layout and instead explicitly space words if required? . There are still issues with word spacing on Mobile Safari even with the changes made in the `incoming` branch. See for example: http://download.vistair.com/pdf2htmlEX/MobileSafariSpacing.pdf The affected HTML is: ```
F2.3 Property (including Fire Protection) 1
``` The key is the sequence `F2.3[space][space]Property...` Chrome/Firefox etc collapse the 2 spaces and treat the text as `F2.3[space]Property` = 2 words with a single word space, however Mobile Safari is treating the 2 spaces separately and inserting a word-space between them which shifts everything else to the right on the line. Given how inconsistent word-spacing is being applied between browsers, is it possible to avoid its use? . My current workaround is to convert the first space of a text node which begins with a space to a non-break space (\u00a0). This corrects the issue on Mobile Safari. I haven't looked at how this affects Chrome/IE/Firefox. I will run some tests and let you know. . I have done some testing with this example, and replacing the first leading space with a non-break space means this page renders now correctly on Mobile Safari/Chrome/IE/Firefox. . `--space-as-offset 1` is sufficient for it to render correctly on Mobile Safari. This is Safari that comes with iOS 8.1. It says "AppleWekKit/600.1.4". I'm not sure how that relates to the base WebKit version. Is there a downside to using `--space-as-offset 1`? If not, shouldn't it be the default? . Having done some experimenting with `--space-as-offset 1`, it appears to have some serious bugs - I am seeing letters dropping out in the middle of words. In Firefox the image was still rendered, but in Webkit the background image was not being displayed. You might want to add a check to ensure the minimum height/width of the background image is 1px . I tried pdftocairo 0.24.5 and it lost some lines on the example PDF, but testing with pdftocairo 0.26.3, they were all present so I assumed this issue had been fixed. I didn't realise about the thinlinemode in pdftoppm - that seems like it would be the best solution. Does it really need to be an option or should we just set it to "shape" by default? . And in fact the thinlinemode produces a much better result. So in SplashBackgroundRenderer we just change: ``` SplashBackgroundRenderer::SplashBackgroundRenderer(const string & imgFormat, HTMLRenderer * html_renderer, const Param & param) : SplashOutputDev(splashModeRGB8, 4, gFalse, (SplashColorPtr)(&white), gTrue, gTrue) , html_renderer(html_renderer) , param(param) , format(imgFormat) ``` to ``` SplashBackgroundRenderer::SplashBackgroundRenderer(const string & imgFormat, HTMLRenderer * html_renderer, const Param & param) : SplashOutputDev(splashModeRGB8, 4, gFalse, (SplashColorPtr)(&white), gTrue, gTrue, splashThinLineShape) , html_renderer(html_renderer) , param(param) , format(imgFormat) ``` Is any reason why you would _not_ want to enable thinlinemode? . Actually the default for Splash is not strictly "none". From `SplashTypes.h`: ``` enum SplashThinLineMode { splashThinLineDefault, // if SA on: draw solid if requested line width, transformed into // device space, is less than half a pixel and a shaped line else splashThinLineSolid, // draw line solid at least with 1 pixel splashThinLineShape // draw line shaped at least with 1 pixel }; ``` So default behaviour is dependent on the Stroke Adjustment setting in the PDF. However I guess if SA is off, then nothing happens to thin lines and they get dropped which is not good. I'm doing some testing now, but it would seem that splashThinLineShape produces good results - much more uniform line weights than the "solid" setting. . I redone the image counting in setMimeData. Note there are some differences now: - images declared once and used multiple times will only count as one image. - setMimeData is sometimes called on images which don't make it into the output SVG (they are outside the clipped area), resulting in an overestimate of the number of images on the page Neither of these issues are particularly significant . OK but that might take a while as there are several changes in this patch and each will need a separate test case. Most of my own internal test cases are customer data and are not easily distributable in their current form. . As an update to this, `--optimize-text` is also broken in the same way - it should not make any changes to the text unless the character encoding is "standard". There are many subsetted fonts out there that use character 32 as a normal character and _not_ a space. . And also `--space-threshold` is similarly broken. We need a flag for the current font to say "custom font encoding - leave alone", and then skip `--optimize-text`, `--space-as-offset` and `--space-threshold` for characters in that font as they are breaking the output. . It is most likely Chrome being dumb and trying to use a "ti" ligature which doesn't exist in the font. There are CSS rules to turn off this behaviour however they do not work in all cases (e.g. iOS mobile safari). The only robust solution to this is to process all text on the page and split up any potential ligatures. You can either post-process the HTML files to split potential ligatures, or do it on the fly in javascript as follows: ``` var ligatureMatch = new RegExp('([ft])([ftlibhkj])', 'gi'); var htmlMatch = new RegExp("[&<]", "g"); // Horrible hack to stop iPad from trying to use ligatures. We can't use // font-variant-ligatures:none as // this breaks the font metrics for Helvetica Type 1 font function fixLigatures(elem) { if (elem.nodeType == Node.ELEMENT_NODE) { var tag = elem.nodeName.toLowerCase(); if (tag != 'script' && tag != 'style') { for (var i = 0; i < elem.childNodes.length; i++) { fixLigatures(elem.childNodes[i]); } } } else if (elem.nodeType == Node.TEXT_NODE) { if (ligatureMatch.test(elem.nodeValue)) { var newChild = document.createElement("span"); var newText = elem.nodeValue.replace(htmlMatch, function(m) { if (m == "&") { return "&"; } else { return "<"; } }).replace(ligatureMatch, "$1$2"); newChild.innerHTML = newText; elem.parentNode.replaceChild(newChild, elem); } } } // call as follows: fixLigatures(document.body); ``` . I have seen several cases where getNumPoints() == 1 - i.e. there is only one point in the path (just a "moveto") but the path is never closed. In this case the loop will execute at least once, reading garbage for the "second" point. Also in the simple case where the stroked path is just a rectangle, getNumPoints() == 5 but from that you are creating 2 bboxes - one correct one and one zero one (not a big issue as the second just gets ignored but it shows the logic is not right in the loop). You can see this by enabling DrawingTracer debugging. I do have a test case for this. What is the best way of getting it to you? . Also you do not need to do anything for a closed subPath - poppler has already joined up the path for you. From GfxState.cc: ``` void GfxSubpath::close() { if (x[n-1] != x[0] || y[n-1] != y[0]) { lineTo(x[0], y[0]); } closed = gTrue; } ``` . The error info is "can not create directory d". So I change the "--dest-dir" 
into "/myJava/pdf2htmlEX/test", fortunately it workd good!
 It seems that the "--dest-dir" can't  use absolute path in windows(path start with "d:"). I think it will run more good on Linux.
Thanks again!!

peterpisljar:
Hmm, i came across the same problem. i tried removing all the <spans> with _0, _1 and _2 ... formating didnt break much.
. the reson why this bothered me:
- i feel the text pdf2htmlEX generates is really hard to read ( i am using external hint tool as suggested)
- when playing arround with produced html i found out that removing this spans improves readability

here is a document describing the problem (on my google docs):
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VQ3NrSxOKoSinoy5lC2A_ziz8EdLEkAcWagxjjeTlxU/edit?usp=sharing

you can see comparison of pdf, generated html and generated html after spans were removed.
formating didnt break, but the readability improves.

there is still however a problem with font-matching .... the generated fonts are much less readable than the ones in pdf (my feeling), however this doesnt belong in this post.
. yes, ttfautohint

marcobra:
pdf2htmlex in Ubuntu 14.04, please add the follwing ppa:

https://launchpad.net/~fontforge/+archive/ubuntu/fontforge
https://launchpad.net/~coolwanglu/+archive/ubuntu/pdf2htmlex

Then 
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get dist-upgrade
sudo apt-get install pdf2htmlex
sudo apt-get -f install
. pdf2htmlex in Ubuntu 14.04, please add the follwing ppa:

vivin:
I figured this out. Cloning fontforge from your fork clones the master branch. I switched to the `pdf2htmlEX` branch and built it and now everything works!

Perhaps you can mention this in the documentation so that it's easily visible? Thanks once again!
. I found it at https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/wiki/Building.

There it mentions to use your fork, but I didn't see anything about
switching to the pdf2htmlEX branch? I think the problem is that the link to
your fork takes you to the pdf2htmlEX branch, but when you clone it
defaults to the master branch.

josch:
applying commit c0371a07a678bebf2e6991c94eb245ec1c3f95cf on top of 0.11 allowed me to build pdf2html without problems on Debian testing
. I found another problem. Even if a test in the test suite fails, running `make test` does not fail. This is fixed in the patch named `fix-testsuite`.
. Another two problems I solved:

`do-not-ship-unused-js` - this patch does not install the unminified versions of base.css, fancy.css and pdf2htmlEX.js which are never used by the executable.

`use-tmpdir` - on non-windows system, `/tmp` is used for temporary files. Instead, `/tmp` should be the last ressort when no other method is able to return an appropriate temporary directory. So this patch also check the TMPDIR environment variable and some other places.
. Hi @coolwanglu ,
sorry I'm not very familiar with github. Would you like me to create pull requests for anything or is everything resolved?
About `compatibility.js`: did you just remove things that were not necessary or did you remove things that made pdf2htmlEX not work in some situations?

. I found another problem. Even if a test in the test suite fails, running `make test` does not fail. This is fixed in the patch named `fix-testsuite`.
. Another two problems I solved:

`do-not-ship-unused-js` - this patch does not install the unminified versions of base.css, fancy.css and pdf2htmlEX.js which are never used by the executable.

`use-tmpdir` - on non-windows system, `/tmp` is used for temporary files. Instead, `/tmp` should be the last ressort when no other method is able to return an appropriate temporary directory. So this patch also check the TMPDIR environment variable and some other places.

eric-brechemier:
It is not fixed: I also experienced this issue on Ubuntu 12.04 after installing pdf2htmlEX from the Ubuntu PPA today.
. Note: I had `fontforge` already installed on the system:

``` sh
$  dpkg -l | grep fontforge
ii  fontforge                              0.0.20110222-4ubuntu1                          font editor
ii  libfontforge1                          0.0.20110222-4ubuntu1                          font editor - runtime library
```
. Installing `libfontforge-dev` solved the issue for me too:

``` sh
$ sudo apt-get install libfontforge-dev
```
. Note: after installing `libfontforge-dev`:

``` sh
$ dpkg -l | grep fontforge
ii  fontforge                              20141014-0ubuntu1~precise               font editor
ii  fontforge-common                       20141014-0ubuntu1~precise               font editor (common files)
ii  libfontforge1                          20141014-0ubuntu1~precise               font editor - runtime library
```

It seems that `fontforge-common` was the missing requirement.

KrishnaPG:
For the SEO, the basic need is keyword identification, which is difficult when words get split as individual characters. For example, consider the below html generated: ```
Technology Stack
``` The word `Technology` is split in the middle with a span tag. Which makes it impossible for the search engines to classify the document as 'technology' document. The main problem here is, the induced `span` tag is just accounting for `1.09 px` which is not really worth the effort for HTML. For example, here is the rendered html in browser (after turning off the span tag): ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4610831/11736261/e3093e3e-9ff1-11e5-8e03-4c0bd54f745c.png) In PDF the `1.09 px` could make large difference for different devices, but in HTML (which is essentially responsive, meaning different output for different devices), perhaps these intermediate `span` elements below certain threshold should be ignored and not be output (especially when they are breaking words). One possible approach is: ``` * eliminating/minimizing the tags insertion in the mid of text (where there is no white-space) * not generating `span` margins below certain (configurable?) thresholds (e.g. 5 px) * while, retaining the current pixel-level accuracy for non-textual content (images, control sequences etc.) ``` The second requirement for SEO is, using contextual tags, such as `h1, h2, h3...` Presently the generated output uses `div classes` with varying font-size heights specified (such as `
`). Instead, using the `

` tags with the same classes, such as `

` in place of `div` tag is one good option to consider here (after sorting the font-sizes and assigning them in the decreasing order) The next important SEO features are using `title` and `alt` attributes for the links and images. But not sure if that would be easy without some external help. There are other SEQ requirements such as responsiveness and page-loading speed etc. which I think can be tackled by the users. > one good way would be to let users choose between `pixel-perfect (less SEO)` vs `text-perfect (good SEO, but may not be pixel-perfect as the PDF)` when generating the output Like the `zip` and `H.264` codecs work, profiles on the scale of 0 to 9 mapped to `pixel-perfect` to `text-perfect` is one good way to go. Pdf2HtmlEx might be already implementing most of these in one form or the other - its just a matter fine-tuning and figuring out which one works for SEO. . @duanyao It doesn't do nothing for broken links, does it?
. Yes. It contains **BROKEN** links if the links point to anchors in other pages.
. > This phrase just makes most feature requests invalid ones.

pdf2htmlEX focuses on PDF->HTML tranform and usually leaves PDF->PDF and HTML-> HTML tranforms to external tools if possible. Of cause, If anyone want to implement these features in pdf2htmlEX, patches are always welcome.

> One HTML for one page makes sense if each page contains separated content.
> For instance, I can make one page for each chapter and I want to make an HTML for each chapter, that is one page. Or, some PDFs of slides/poster for presentation would contains separated content for each page.

What if some chapters happen to have more than one pages? It seems one-HTML-for-each-page solution doesn't fit all cases.

> Futhermore, generally, for large PDF file with lots of pages, loading all content in one HTML file would impact bad performance. 

`--split-pages` is supposed to solve this problem.

. > This phrase just makes most feature requests invalid ones.

pdf2htmlEX focuses on PDF->HTML tranform and usually leaves PDF->PDF and HTML-> HTML tranforms to external tools if possible. Of cause, If anyone want to implement these features in pdf2htmlEX, patches are always welcome.

> One HTML for one page makes sense if each page contains separated content.
> For instance, I can make one page for each chapter and I want to make an HTML for each chapter, that is one page. Or, some PDFs of slides/poster for presentation would contains separated content for each page.

What if some chapters happen to have more than one pages? It seems one-HTML-for-each-page solution doesn't fit all cases.

> Futhermore, generally, for large PDF file with lots of pages, loading all content in one HTML file would impact bad performance. 

`--split-pages` is supposed to solve this problem.

volago:
Hi,
I've also encountered this issue. We've noticed that everything works properly on admin account, but fails in ordinary user account (permissions to dest dir and temp dir were ok). Next we used Process Monitor, a it turned out that pdf2htmlEX.exe tries to save some files in root folder on drive it was launched.

Once we added write permissions to root folder the program finished with successes.

It seems that there are 2 types of temp files: one in configurable temp dir, and the second in root folder. Files are removed after pdf2htmlEX finishes.. Hi,
I've also encountered this issue. We've noticed that everything works properly on admin account, but fails in ordinary user account (permissions to dest dir and temp dir were ok). Next we used Process Monitor, a it turned out that pdf2htmlEX.exe tries to save some files in root folder on drive it was launched.

Once we added write permissions to root folder the program finished with successes.

It seems that there are 2 types of temp files: one in configurable temp dir, and the second in root folder. Files are removed after pdf2htmlEX finishes..

maxholman:
A workaround to display the missing characters is to deactivate common ligatures for Webkit, with the following CSS:

`-webkit-font-variant-ligatures: no-common-ligatures;`
. A workaround to display the missing characters is to deactivate common ligatures for Webkit, with the following CSS:

`-webkit-font-variant-ligatures: no-common-ligatures;`

kapilsharma:
Yes, problem is happening when cursor is between two lines. It do not cause much problem (Still not good) on desktop but on tablets/mobile device, it is frustrating where we do not have sharp mouse pointer but fat finger.
. Thanks for reply @duanyao 

Problem occurs when pointer goes in empty space. However even in test file you mentioned, it can be reproduced as follow:

**Test case**
- On note on left most of file, click and drag from starting 

```
Ce premier cha-
pitre eﬅ fort diﬃ-
cile : & por cette
caſe, il
```
- While mouse button still down (selecting text), take mouse pointer between third and fourth line, below `&`, after `fe,` and before `il`.
- You will find issue reproduced and selection is not what we expected.

However real test case should be, if there is some space between text (text with double line spacing is most crucial test case), and while selecting if mouse reach in that space, selection distort.

**This is crucial for mobile devices**, where we do not have sharp mouse pointer and issue occur frequently.

Version I used

``` bash
pdf2htmlEX --version
pdf2htmlEX version 0.12
Copyright 2012-2014 Lu Wang <coolwanglu@gmail.com> and other contributors
Libraries: 
  poppler 0.24.5
  libfontforge 20141104
  cairo 1.13.1
Default data-dir: /usr/share/pdf2htmlEX
Supported image format: png jpg svg
```
. Test case on online version http://coolwanglu.github.io/pdf2htmlEX/demo/geneve.html
- On note on right hand side of file, start selecting first para

```
porqoy les He-
briex cõmencent
le ior natrel le
ſoir apres le ſoleil
couchant.
g
Ce mot
```
- While mouse button still down (selecting text), take mouse pointer to end of para in white space after `couchant.`
- You will find issue reproduced and selection is not what we expected.
. Please note: Issue is only in Firefox.
We tried this in Chrome and IE but issue not reproduced there.

przemekklosowski:
This problem is caused by 
https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX/commit/f30520c217a017dcb080bda8c8c2240309aeb83e
The error message is clear: on  Fedora 22 we have GfxFontLoc *locateFont(XRef *xref, GBool ps) so the second argument has to be gFalse. Make completes successfully when 3rdparty/poppler/git/CairoFontEngine.cc:422 is changed accordingly. 

Please either revert this or check for the appropriate form during configuration.
